Low Density Lattice Codes

NaftaliÂ Sommer,Â  MeirÂ Feder,Â  andÂ OfirÂ Shalvi The material in this paper was presented in part in the IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory, Seattle, July 2006, and in part in the Inauguration of the UCSD Information Theory and Applications Center, San Diego, Feb. 2006.
Abstract

Low density lattice codes (LDLC) are novel lattice codes that can be decoded efficiently and approach the capacity of the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel. In LDLC a codeword xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is generated directly at the nğ‘›n-dimensional Euclidean space as a linear transformation of a corresponding integer message vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, i.e., xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where ğ‘¯=ğ‘®âˆ’1ğ‘¯superscriptğ‘®1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1} is restricted to be sparse. The fact that ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is sparse is utilized to develop a linear-time iterative decoding scheme which attains, as demonstrated by simulations, good error performance within âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5\sim 0.5dB from capacity at block length of n=100,000ğ‘›100000n=100,000 symbols. The paper also discusses convergence results and implementation considerations.

Index Terms:
Lattices, lattice codes, iterative decoding, LDPC.

I Introduction

If we take a look at the evolution of codes for binary or finite alphabet channels, it was first shown [1] that channel capacity can be achieved with long random codewords. Then, it was found out [2] that capacity can be achieved via a simpler structure of linear codes. Then, specific families of linear codes were found that are practical and have good minimum Hamming distance (e.g. convolutional codes, cyclic block codes, specific cyclic codes such as BCH and Reed-Solomon codes [4]). Later, capacity achieving schemes were found, which have special structures that allow efficient iterative decoding, such as low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes [5] or turbo codes [6].

If we now take a similar look at continuous alphabet codes for the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, it was first shown [3] that codes with long random Gaussian codewords can achieve capacity. Later, it was shown that lattice codes can also achieve capacity ([7] â€“ [12]). Lattice codes are clearly the Euclidean space analogue of linear codes. Similarly to binary codes, we could expect that specific practical lattice codes will then be developed. However, there was almost no further progress from that point. Specific lattice codes that were found were based on fixed dimensional classical lattices [19] or based on algebraic error correcting codes [13][14], but no significant effort was made in designing lattice codes directly in the Euclidean space or in finding specific capacity achieving lattice codes. Practical coding schemes for the AWGN channel were based on finite alphabet codes.

In [15], â€œsignal codesâ€ were introduced. These are lattice codes, designed directly in the Euclidean space, where the information sequence of integers insubscriptğ‘–ğ‘›i_{n}, n=1,2,â€¦ğ‘›12â€¦n=1,2,... is encoded by convolving it with a fixed signal pattern gnsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘›g_{n}, n=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘›12â€¦ğ‘‘n=1,2,...d. Signal codes are clearly analogous to convolutional codes, and in particular can work at the AWGN channel cutoff rate with simple sequential decoders. In [16] it is also demonstrated that signal codes can work near the AWGN channel capacity with more elaborated bi-directional decoders. Thus, signal codes provided the first step toward finding effective lattice codes with practical decoders.

Inspired by LDPC codes and in the quest of finding practical capacity achieving lattice codes, we propose in this work â€œLow Density Lattice Codesâ€ (LDLC). We show that these codes can approach the AWGN channel capacity with iterative decoders whose complexity is linear in block length. In recent years several schemes were proposed for using LDPC over continuous valued channels by either multilevel coding [18] or by non-binary alphabet (e.g. [17]). Unlike these LDPC based schemes, in LDLC both the encoder and the channel use the same real algebra which is natural for the continuous-valued AWGN channel. This feature also simplifies the convergence analysis of the iterative decoder.

The outline of this paper is as follows. Low density lattice codes are first defined in Section II. The iterative decoder is then presented in Section III, followed by convergence analysis of the decoder in Section IV. Then, Section V describes how to choose the LDLC code parameters, and Section VI discusses implementation considerations. The computational complexity of the decoder is then discussed in Section VII, followed by a brief description of encoding and shaping in Section VIII. Simulation results are finally presented in Section IX.

II Basic Definitions and Properties

II-A Lattices and Lattice Codes

An nğ‘›n dimensional lattice in â„msuperscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathbb{R}^{m} is defined as the set of all linear combinations of a given basis of nğ‘›n linearly independent vectors in â„msuperscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathbb{R}^{m} with integer coefficients. The matrix ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G}, whose columns are the basis vectors, is called a generator matrix of the lattice. Every lattice point is therefore of the form xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} is an nğ‘›n-dimensional vector of integers. The Voronoi cell of a lattice point is defined as the set of all points that are closer to this point than to any other lattice point. The Voronoi cells of all lattice points are congruent, and for square ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} the volume of the Voronoi cell is equal to dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘®)ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘®det(\boldsymbol{G}). In the sequel ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} will be used to denote both the lattice and its generator matrix.

A lattice code of dimension nğ‘›n is defined by a (possibly shifted) lattice ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} in â„msuperscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathbb{R}^{m} and a shaping region BâŠ‚â„mğµsuperscriptâ„ğ‘šB\subset\mathbb{R}^{m}, where the codewords are all the lattice points that lie within the shaping region BğµB. Denote the number of these codewords by Nğ‘N. The average transmitted power (per channel use, or per symbol) is the average energy of all codewords, divided by the codeword length mğ‘šm. The information rate (in bits/symbol) is lâ€‹oâ€‹g2â€‹(N)/mğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”2ğ‘ğ‘šlog_{2}(N)/m.

When using a lattice code for the AWGN channel with power limit Pğ‘ƒP and noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, the maximal information rate is limited by the capacity 12â€‹log2â¡(1+PÏƒ2)12subscript21ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}(1+\frac{P}{\sigma^{2}}). Poltyrev [20] considered the AWGN channel without restrictions. If there is no power restriction, code rate is a meaningless measure, since it can be increased without limit. Instead, it was suggested in [20] to use the measure of constellation density, leading to a generalized definition of the capacity as the maximal possible codeword density that can be recovered reliably. When applied to lattices, the generalized capacity implies that there exists a lattice ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} of high enough dimension nğ‘›n that enables transmission with arbitrary small error probability, if and only if Ïƒ2<|dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘®)|2n2â€‹Ï€â€‹esuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘®22ğœ‹ğ‘’\sigma^{2}<\frac{\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{G})|^{2}}}{2\pi e}. A lattice that achieves the generalized capacity of the AWGN channel without restrictions, also achieves the channel capacity of the power constrained AWGN channel, with a properly chosen spherical shaping region (see also [12]).

In the rest of this work we shall concentrate on the lattice design and the lattice decoding algorithm, and not on the shaping region or shaping algorithms. We shall use lattices with dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘®)=1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘®1det(\boldsymbol{G})=1, where analysis and simulations will be carried for the AWGN channel without restrictions. A capacity achieving lattice will have small error probability for noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} which is close to the theoretical limit 12â€‹Ï€â€‹e12ğœ‹ğ‘’\frac{1}{2\pi e}.

II-B Syndrome and Parity Check Matrix for Lattice Codes

A binary (n,k)ğ‘›ğ‘˜(n,k) error correcting code is defined by its nÃ—kğ‘›ğ‘˜n\times k binary generator matrix ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G}. A binary information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} with dimension kğ‘˜k is encoded by xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where calculations are performed in the finite field GF(2). The parity check matrix ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is an (nâˆ’k)Ã—nğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘›(n-k)\times n matrix such that xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is a codeword if and only if ğ‘¯â€‹xÂ¯=0Â¯ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯0\boldsymbol{H}\underline{x}=\underline{0}. The input to the decoder is the noisy codeword yÂ¯=xÂ¯+eÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘’\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{e}, where eÂ¯Â¯ğ‘’\underline{e} is the error sequence and addition is done in the finite field. The decoder typically starts by calculating the syndrome sÂ¯=ğ‘¯â€‹yÂ¯=ğ‘¯â€‹(xÂ¯+eÂ¯)=ğ‘¯â€‹eÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘’ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘’\underline{s}=\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}=\boldsymbol{H}(\underline{x}+\underline{e})=\boldsymbol{H}\underline{e} which depends only on the noise sequence and not on the transmitted codeword.

We would now like to extend the definitions of the parity check matrix and the syndrome to lattice codes. An nğ‘›n-dimensional lattice code is defined by its nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n lattice generator matrix ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} (throughout this paper we assume that ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} is square, but the results are easily extended to the non-square case). Every codeword is of the form xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, where bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} is a vector of integers. Therefore, ğ‘®âˆ’1â€‹xÂ¯superscriptğ‘®1Â¯ğ‘¥\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}\underline{x} is a vector of integers for every codeword xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}. We define the parity check matrix for the lattice code as ğ‘¯=Î”ğ‘®âˆ’1superscriptÎ”ğ‘¯superscriptğ‘®1\boldsymbol{H}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}. Given a noisy codeword yÂ¯=xÂ¯+wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{w} (where wğ‘¤w is the additive noise vector, e.g. AWGN, added by real arithmetic), we can then define the syndrome as sÂ¯=Î”fâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹{ğ‘¯â€‹yÂ¯}superscriptÎ”Â¯ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}\}, where fâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹{x}ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥frac\{x\} is the fractional part of xğ‘¥x, defined as frac{x}=xâˆ’âŒŠxâŒ‰frac\{x\}=x-\left\lfloor x\right\rceil, where âŒŠxâŒ‰delimited-âŒŠâŒ‰ğ‘¥\left\lfloor x\right\rceil denotes the nearest integer to xğ‘¥x. The syndrome sÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ \underline{s} will be zero if and only if yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} is a lattice point, since ğ‘¯â€‹yÂ¯ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¦\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y} will then be a vector of integers with zero fractional part. For a noisy codeword, the syndrome will equal sÂ¯=fâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹{ğ‘¯â€‹yÂ¯}=fâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹{ğ‘¯â€‹(xÂ¯+wÂ¯)}=fâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹{ğ‘¯â€‹wÂ¯}Â¯ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¤ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{s}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{y}\}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}(\underline{x}+\underline{w})\}=frac\{\boldsymbol{H}\underline{w}\} and therefore will depend only on the noise sequence and not on the transmitted codeword, as desired.

Note that the above definitions of the syndrome and parity check matrix for lattice codes are consistent with the definitions of the dual lattice and the dual code[19]: the dual lattice of a lattice ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} is defined as the lattice with generator matrix ğ‘¯=ğ‘®âˆ’1ğ‘¯superscriptğ‘®1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}, where for binary codes, the dual code of ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} is defined as the code whose generator matrix is ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, the parity check matrix of ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G}.

II-C Low Density Lattice Codes

We shall now turn to the definition of the codes proposed in this paper - low density lattice codes (LDLC).

Definition 1 (LDLC)

An nğ‘›n dimensional LDLC is an nğ‘›n-dimensional lattice code with a non-singular lattice generator matrix ğ†ğ†\boldsymbol{G} satisfying |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ†)|=1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ†1|det(\boldsymbol{G})|=1, for which the parity check matrix ğ‡=ğ†âˆ’1ğ‡superscriptğ†1\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{-1} is sparse. The iğ‘–iâ€™th row degree risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘›i=1,2,...n is defined as the number of nonzero elements in row iğ‘–i of ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H}, and the iğ‘–iâ€™th column degree cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘›i=1,2,...n is defined as the number of nonzero elements in column iğ‘–i of ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H}.

Note that in binary LDPC codes, the code is completely defined by the locations of the nonzero elements of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}. In LDLC there is another degree of freedom since we also have to choose the values of the nonzero elements of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}.

Definition 2 (regular LDLC)

An nğ‘›n dimensional LDLC is regular if all the row degrees and column degrees of the parity check matrix are equal to a common degree dğ‘‘d.

Definition 3 (magic square LDLC)

An nğ‘›n dimensional regular LDLC with degree dğ‘‘d is called â€œmagic square LDLCâ€ if every row and column of the parity check matrix ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H} has the same dğ‘‘d nonzero values, except for a possible change of order and random signs. The sorted sequence of these dğ‘‘d values h1â‰¥h2â‰¥â€¦â‰¥hd>0subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘0h_{1}\geq h_{2}\geq...\geq h_{d}>0 will be referred to as the generating sequence of the magic square LDLC.

For example, the matrix

ğ‡=(0âˆ’0.80âˆ’0.5100.80010âˆ’0.500.5100.8000âˆ’0.5âˆ’0.80110000.50.80.5âˆ’1âˆ’0.8000)ğ‡00.800.5100.800100.500.5100.80000.50.80110000.50.80.510.8000\mathbf{\boldsymbol{H}}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cccccc}0&-0.8&0&-0.5&1&0\\ 0.8&0&0&1&0&-0.5\\ 0&0.5&1&0&0.8&0\\ 0&0&-0.5&-0.8&0&1\\ 1&0&0&0&0.5&0.8\\ 0.5&-1&-0.8&0&0&0\end{array}\right)

is a parity check matrix of a magic square LDLC with lattice dimension n=6ğ‘›6n=6, degree d=3ğ‘‘3d=3 and generating sequence {1,0.8,0.5}10.80.5\{1,0.8,0.5\}. This ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} should be further normalized by the constant |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|nğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|} in order to have |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|=|dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘®)|=1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘®1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=|det(\boldsymbol{G})|=1, as required by Definition 1.

The bipartite graph of an LDLC is defined similarly to LDPC codes: it is a graph with variable nodes at one side and check nodes at the other side. Each variable node corresponds to a single element of the codeword xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Each check node corresponds to a check equation (a row of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}). A check equation is of the form âˆ‘khkâ€‹xik=iâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ\sum_{k}h_{k}x_{i_{k}}=integer, where iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k} denotes the locations of the nonzero elements at the appropriate row of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k} are the values of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} at these locations and the integer at the right hand side is unknown. An edge connects check node iğ‘–i and variable node jğ‘—j if and only if Hi,jâ‰ 0subscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘—0H_{i,j}\neq 0. This edge is assigned the value Hi,jsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘—H_{i,j}. Figure 1 illustrates the bi-partite graph of a magic square LDLC with degree 3. In the figure, every variable node xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is also associated with its noisy channel observation yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k}.

Finally, a kğ‘˜k-loop is defined as a loop in the bipartite graph that consists of kğ‘˜k edges. A bipartite graph, in general, can only contain loops with even length. Also, a 2-loop, which consists of two parallel edges that originate from the same variable node to the same check node, is not possible by the definition of the graph. However, longer loops are certainly possible. For example, a 4-loop exists when two variable nodes are both connected to the same pair of check nodes.

III Iterative Decoding for the AWGN Channel

Assume that the codeword xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b} was transmitted, where bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} is a vector of integers. We observe the noisy codeword yÂ¯=xÂ¯+wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{w}, where wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{w} is a vector of i.i.d Gaussian noise samples with common variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, and we need to estimate the integer valued vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. The maximum likelihood (ML) estimator is then bÂ¯^=argâ€‹minbÂ¯â€–yÂ¯âˆ’ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯â€–2^Â¯ğ‘subscriptÂ¯ğ‘superscriptnormÂ¯ğ‘¦ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘2\hat{\underline{b}}=\arg\mathop{\min}\limits_{\underline{b}}||\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}||^{2}.

Our decoder will not estimate directly the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. Instead, it will estimate the probability density function (PDF) of the codeword vector xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}. Furthermore, instead of calculating the nğ‘›n-dimensional PDF of the whole vector xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}, we shall calculate the nğ‘›n one-dimensional PDFâ€™s for each of the components xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} of this vector (conditioned on the whole observation vector yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}). In appendix A it is shown that fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) is a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions:

fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)=Câ‹…âˆ‘lÂ¯âˆˆğ‘®âˆ©BÎ´â€‹(xkâˆ’lk)â‹…eâˆ’d2â€‹(lÂ¯,yÂ¯)/2â€‹Ïƒ2subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦â‹…ğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘®ğµâ‹…ğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘™ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘‘2Â¯ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘¦2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y})=C\cdot\sum_{\underline{l}\in\boldsymbol{G}\cap B}\delta(x_{k}-l_{k})\cdot e^{-d^{2}(\underline{l},\underline{y})/2\sigma^{2}} (1)

where lÂ¯Â¯ğ‘™\underline{l} is a lattice point (vector), lksubscriptğ‘™ğ‘˜l_{k} is its kğ‘˜k-th component, Cğ¶C is a constant independent of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} and dâ€‹(lÂ¯,yÂ¯)ğ‘‘Â¯ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘¦d(\underline{l},\underline{y}) is the Euclidean distance between lÂ¯Â¯ğ‘™\underline{l} and yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}. Direct evaluation of (1) is not practical, so our decoder will try to estimate fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) (or at least approximate it) in an iterative manner.

Our decoder will decode to the infinite lattice, thus ignoring the shaping region boundaries. This approximate decoding method is no longer exact maximum likelihood decoding, and is usually denoted â€œlattice decodingâ€ [12].

The calculation of fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) is involved since the components xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} are not independent random variables (RVâ€™s), because xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is restricted to be a lattice point. Following [5] we use a â€œtrickâ€ - we assume that the xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}â€™s are independent, but add a condition that assures that xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is a lattice point. Specifically, define sÂ¯=Î”ğ‘¯â‹…xÂ¯superscriptÎ”Â¯ğ‘ â‹…ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. Restricting xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} to be a lattice point is equivalent to restricting sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nÂ¯ğ‘ superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}. Therefore, instead of calculating fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}) under the assumption that xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is a lattice point, we can calculate fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯,sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤n)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘ superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}) and assume that the xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) with a continuous PDF (that does not include Dirac delta functions). It still remains to set fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}), the PDF of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. Under the i.i.d assumption, the PDF of the codeword xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)=âˆk=1nfxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}). As shown in Appendix B, the value of fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) is not important at values of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} which are not lattice points, but at a lattice point it should be proportional to the probability of using this lattice point. Since we assume that all lattice points are used equally likely, fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) must have the same value at all lattice points. A reasonable choice for fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) is then to use a uniform distribution such that xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} will be uniformly distributed in an nğ‘›n-dimensional cube. For an exact ML decoder (that takes into account the boundaries of the shaping region), it is enough to choose the range of fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) such that this cube will contain the shaping region. For our decoder, that performs lattice decoding, we should set the range of fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) large enough such that the resulting cube will include all the lattice points which are likely to be decoded. The derivation of the iterative decoder shows that this range can be set as large as needed without affecting the complexity of the decoder.

The derivation in [5] further imposed the tree assumption. In order to understand the tree assumption, it is useful to define the tier diagram, which is shown in Figure 2 for a regular LDLC with degree 3. Each vertical line corresponds to a check equation. The tier 1 nodes of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} are all the elements xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} that take place in a check equation with x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}. The tier 2 nodes of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} are all the elements that take place in check equations with the tier 1 elements of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}, and so on. The tree assumption assumes that all the tree elements are distinct (i.e. no element appears in different tiers or twice in the same tier). This assumption simplifies the derivation, but in general, does not hold in practice, so our iterative algorithm is not guaranteed to converge to the exact solution (1) (see Section IV).

The detailed derivation of the iterative decoder (using the above â€œtrickâ€ and the tree assumption) is given in Appendix C. In Section III-A below we present the final resulting algorithm. This iterative algorithm can also be explained by intuitive arguments, described after the algorithm specification.

III-A The Iterative Decoding Algorithm

The iterative algorithm is most conveniently represented by using a message passing scheme over the bipartite graph of the code, similarly to LDPC codes. The basic difference is that in LDPC codes the messages are scalar values (e.g. the log likelihood ratio of a bit), where for LDLC the messages are real functions over the interval (âˆ’âˆ,âˆ)(-\infty,\infty). As in LDPC, in each iteration the check nodes send messages to the variable nodes along the edges of the bipartite graph and vice versa. The messages sent by the check nodes are periodic extensions of PDFâ€™s. The messages sent by the variable nodes are PDFâ€™s.

LDLC iterative decoding algorithm:

Denote the variable nodes by x1,x2,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n} and the check nodes by c1,c2,â€¦â€‹cnsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{1},c_{2},...c_{n}.

  • â€¢

    Initialization: each variable node xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} sends to all its check nodes the message fk(0)â€‹(x)=12â€‹Ï€â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹eâˆ’(ykâˆ’x)22â€‹Ïƒ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜0ğ‘¥12ğœ‹superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥22superscriptğœ2f_{k}^{(0)}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}.

  • â€¢

    Basic iteration - check node message: Each check node sends a (different) message to each of the variable nodes that are connected to it. For a specific check node denote (without loss of generality) the appropriate check equation by âˆ‘l=1rhlâ€‹xml=iâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹rsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ\sum_{l=1}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}=integer, where xmlsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘™x_{m_{l}}, l=1,2â€‹â€¦â€‹rğ‘™12â€¦ğ‘Ÿl=1,2...r are the variable nodes that are connected to this check node (and rğ‘Ÿr is the appropriate row degree of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}). Denote by flâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™ğ‘¥f_{l}(x), l=1,2â€‹â€¦â€‹rğ‘™12â€¦ğ‘Ÿl=1,2...r, the message that was sent to this check node by variable node xmlsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘™x_{m_{l}} in the previous half-iteration. The message that the check node transmits back to variable node xmjsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—x_{m_{j}} is calculated in three basic steps.

    1. 1.

      The convolution step - all messages, except fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x), are convolved (after expanding each flâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™ğ‘¥f_{l}(x) by hlsubscriptâ„ğ‘™h_{l}):

      p~j(x)=f1(xh1)âŠ›â‹¯fjâˆ’1(xhjâˆ’1)âŠ›\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{j}(x)=f_{1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{1}}\right)\circledast\cdots f_{j-1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{j-1}}\right)\circledast
      âŠ›fj+1â€‹(xhj+1)âŠ›â‹¯â€‹â‹¯âŠ›frâ€‹(xhr)âŠ›absentâŠ›âŠ›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—1ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘—1â‹¯â‹¯subscriptğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\circledast f_{j+1}\left(\frac{x}{h_{j+1}}\right)\circledast\cdots\cdots\circledast f_{r}\left(\frac{x}{h_{r}}\right) (2)
    2. 2.

      The stretching step - The result is stretched by (âˆ’hj)subscriptâ„ğ‘—(-h_{j}) to pjâ€‹(x)=p~jâ€‹(âˆ’hjâ€‹x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘¥p_{j}(x)=\tilde{p}_{j}(-h_{j}x)

    3. 3.

      The periodic extension step - The result is extended to a periodic function with period 1/|hj|1subscriptâ„ğ‘—1/|h_{j}|:

      Qjâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘i=âˆ’âˆâˆpjâ€‹(xâˆ’ihj)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘—\displaystyle Q_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}p_{j}\left(x-\frac{i}{h_{j}}\right) (3)

    The function Qjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥Q_{j}(x) is the message that is finally sent to variable node xmjsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—x_{m_{j}}.

  • â€¢

    Basic iteration - variable node message: Each variable node sends a (different) message to each of the check nodes that are connected to it. For a specific variable node xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, assume that it is connected to check nodes cm1,cm2,â€¦â€‹cmesubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘š2â€¦subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘’c_{m_{1}},c_{m_{2}},...c_{m_{e}}, where eğ‘’e is the appropriate column degree of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}. Denote by Qlâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘™ğ‘¥Q_{l}(x), l=1,2,â€¦â€‹eğ‘™12â€¦ğ‘’l=1,2,...e, the message that was sent from check node cmlsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘™c_{m_{l}} to this variable node in the previous half-iteration. The message that is sent back to check node cmjsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘—c_{m_{j}} is calculated in two basic steps:

    1. 1.

      The product step: f~jâ€‹(x)=eâˆ’(ykâˆ’x)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆl=1lâ‰ jeQlâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥22superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘—ğ‘’subscriptğ‘„ğ‘™ğ‘¥\tilde{f}_{j}(x)=e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq j\end{subarray}}^{e}Q_{l}(x)

    2. 2.

      The normalization step: fjâ€‹(x)=f~jâ€‹(x)âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆf~jâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘xsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptsubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥f_{j}(x)=\frac{\tilde{f}_{j}(x)}{\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{f}_{j}(x)dx}

    This basic iteration is repeated for the desired number of iterations.

  • â€¢

    Final decision: After finishing the iterations, we want to estimate the integer information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. First, we estimate the final PDFâ€™s of the codeword elements xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, k=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘˜12â€¦ğ‘›k=1,2,...n, by calculating the variable node messages at the last iteration without omitting any check node message in the product step: f~fâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹aâ€‹l(k)â€‹(x)=eâˆ’(ykâˆ’x)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆl=1eQlâ€‹(x)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¥22superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘™1ğ‘’subscriptğ‘„ğ‘™ğ‘¥\tilde{f}^{(k)}_{final}(x)=e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{l=1}^{e}Q_{l}(x). Then, we estimate each xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} by finding the peak of its PDF: xk^=aâ€‹râ€‹gâ€‹maxxâ¡f~fâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹aâ€‹l(k)â€‹(x)^subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘¥\hat{x_{k}}=arg\max_{x}\tilde{f}^{(k)}_{final}(x). Finally, we estimate bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} as bÂ¯^=âŒŠğ‘¯xÂ¯^âŒ‰\underline{\hat{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\underline{\hat{x}}\right\rceil.

The operation of the iterative algorithm can be intuitively explained as follows. The check node operation is equivalent to calculating the PDF of xmjsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—x_{m_{j}} from the PDFâ€™s of xmisubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘–x_{m_{i}}, i=1,2,â€¦,jâˆ’1,j+1,â€¦â€‹rğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘—1ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘Ÿi=1,2,...,j-1,j+1,...r, given that âˆ‘l=1rhlâ€‹xml=iâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹rsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ\sum_{l=1}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}=integer, and assuming that xmisubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘–x_{m_{i}} are independent. Extracting xmjsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—x_{m_{j}} from the check equation, we get xmj=1hjâ€‹(iâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹râˆ’âˆ‘l=1lâ‰ jrhlâ€‹xml)subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—1subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘™x_{m_{j}}=\frac{1}{h_{j}}(integer-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq j\end{subarray}}^{r}h_{l}x_{m_{l}}). Since the PDF of a sum of independent random variables is the convolution of the corresponding PDFâ€™s, equation (1) and the stretching step that follows it simply calculate the PDF of xmjsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘šğ‘—x_{m_{j}}, assuming that the integer at the right hand side of the check equation is zero. The result is then periodically extended such that a properly shifted copy exists for every possible value of this (unknown) integer. The variable node gets such a message from all the check equations that involve the corresponding variable. The check node messages and the channel PDF are treated as independent sources of information on the variable, so they are multiplied all together.

Note that the periodic extension step at the check nodes is equivalent to a convolution with an infinite impulse train. With this observation, the operation of the variable nodes is completely analogous to that of the check nodes: the variable nodes multiply the incoming messages by the channel PDF, where the check nodes convolve the incoming messages with an impulse train, which can be regarded as a generalized â€œinteger PDFâ€.

In the above formulation, the integer information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} is recovered from the PDFâ€™s of the codeword elements xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. An alternative approach is to calculate the PDF of each integer element bmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šb_{m} directly as the PDF of the left hand side of the appropriate check equation. Using the tree assumption, this can be done by simply calculating the convolution p~â€‹(x)~ğ‘ğ‘¥\tilde{p}(x) as in (1), but this time without omitting any PDF, i.e. all the received variable node messages are convolved. Then, the integer bmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šb_{m} is determined by b^m=aâ€‹râ€‹gâ€‹maxjâˆˆâ„¤â¡p~â€‹(j)subscript^ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘”subscriptğ‘—â„¤~ğ‘ğ‘—\hat{b}_{m}=arg\max_{j\in\mathbb{Z}}\tilde{p}(j).

Figure 3 shows an example for a regular LDLC with degree d=5ğ‘‘5d=5. The figure shows all the signals that are involved in generating a variable node message for a certain variable node. The top signal is the channel Gaussian, centered around the noisy observation of the variable. The next 4 signals are the periodically extended PDFâ€™s that arrived from the check nodes, and the bottom signal is the product of all the 5 signals. It can be seen that each periodic signal has a different period, according to the relevant coefficient of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}. Also, the signals with larger period have larger variance. This diversity resolves all the ambiguities such that the multiplication result (bottom plot) remains with a single peak. We expect the iterative algorithm to converge to a solution where a single peak will remain at each PDF, located at the desired value and narrow enough to estimate the information.

IV Convergence

IV-A The Gaussian Mixture Model

Interestingly, for LDLC we can come up with a convergence analysis that in many respects is more specific than the similar analysis for LDPC.

We start by introducing basic claims about Gaussian PDFâ€™s. Denote Gm,Vâ€‹(x)=12â€‹Ï€â€‹Vâ€‹eâˆ’(xâˆ’m)22â€‹Vsubscriptğºğ‘šğ‘‰ğ‘¥12ğœ‹ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘š22ğ‘‰G_{m,V}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi V}}e^{-\frac{(x-m)^{2}}{2V}}.

Claim 1 (convolution of Gaussians)

The convolution of nğ‘›n Gaussians with mean values m1,m2,â€¦,mnsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›m_{1},m_{2},...,m_{n} and variances V1,V2,â€¦,Vnsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{1},V_{2},...,V_{n}, respectively, is a Gaussian with mean m1+m2+â€¦+mnsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›m_{1}+m_{2}+...+m_{n} and variance V1+V2+â€¦+Vnsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{1}+V_{2}+...+V_{n}.

Proof:

See [21]. âˆ

Claim 2 (product of nğ‘›n Gaussians)

Let Gm1,V1â€‹(x)subscriptğºsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘‰1ğ‘¥G_{m_{1},V_{1}}(x), Gm2,V2â€‹(x)subscriptğºsubscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘‰2ğ‘¥G_{m_{2},V_{2}}(x),â€¦,Gmn,Vnâ€‹(x)subscriptğºsubscriptğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘¥G_{m_{n},V_{n}}(x) be nğ‘›n Gaussians with mean values m1,m2,â€¦,mnsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›m_{1},m_{2},...,m_{n} and variances V1,V2,â€¦,Vnsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{1},V_{2},...,V_{n} respectively. Then, the product of these Gaussians is a scaled Gaussian: âˆi=1nGmi,Viâ€‹(x)=A^â‹…Gm^,V^â€‹(x)superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğºsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘¥â‹…^ğ´subscriptğº^ğ‘š^ğ‘‰ğ‘¥\prod_{i=1}^{n}G_{m_{i},V_{i}}(x)=\hat{A}\cdot G_{\hat{m},\hat{V}}(x), where 1V^=âˆ‘i=1n1Vi1^ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–\frac{1}{\hat{V}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{V_{i}}, m^=âˆ‘i=1nmiâ€‹Viâˆ’1âˆ‘i=1nViâˆ’1^ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1\hat{m}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}V_{i}^{-1}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}V_{i}^{-1}}, and A^=1(2â€‹Ï€)nâˆ’1â€‹V^âˆ’1â€‹âˆk=1nVkâ‹…eâˆ’V^2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‘j=i+1n(miâˆ’mj)2Viâ‹…Vj^ğ´â‹…1superscript2ğœ‹ğ‘›1superscript^ğ‘‰1superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’^ğ‘‰2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘—2â‹…subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—\hat{A}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(2\pi)^{n-1}\hat{V}^{-1}\prod_{k=1}^{n}V_{k}}}\cdot e^{-\frac{\hat{V}}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=i+1}^{n}\frac{(m_{i}-m_{j})^{2}}{V_{i}\cdot V_{j}}}.

Proof:

By straightforward mathematical manipulations. âˆ

The reason that we are interested in the properties of Gaussian PDFâ€™s lies in the following lemma.

Lemma 1

Each message that is exchanged between the check nodes and variable nodes in the LDLC decoding algorithm (i.e. Qjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥Q_{j}(x) and fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x)), at every iteration, can be expressed as a Gaussian mixture of the form Mâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘j=1âˆAjâ€‹Gmj,Vjâ€‹(x)ğ‘€ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğºsubscriptğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—ğ‘¥M(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}A_{j}G_{m_{j},V_{j}}(x).

Proof:

By induction: The initial messages are Gaussians, and the basic operations of the iterative decoder preserve the Gaussian mixture nature of Gaussian mixture inputs (convolution and multiplication preserve the Gaussian nature according to claims 1 and 2, stretching, expanding and shifting preserve it by the definition of a Gaussian, and periodic extension transforms a single Gaussian to a mixture and a mixture to a mixture). âˆ

Convergence analysis should therefore analyze the convergence of the variances, mean values and amplitudes of the Gaussians in each mixture.

IV-B Convergence of the Variances

We shall now analyze the behavior of the variances, and start with the following lemma.

Lemma 2

For both variable node messages and check node messages, all the Gaussians that take place in the same mixture have the same variance.

Proof:

By induction. The initial variable node messages are single element mixtures so the claim obviously holds. Assume now that all the variable node messages at iteration tğ‘¡t are mixtures where all the Gaussians that take place in the same mixture have the same variance. In the convolution step (1), each variable node message is first expanded. All Gaussians in the expanded mixture will still have the same variance, since the whole mixture is expanded together. Then, dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 expanded Gaussian mixtures are convolved. In the resulting mixture, each Gaussian will be the result of convolving dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 single Gaussians, one from each mixture. According to claim 1, all the Gaussians in the convolution result will have the same variance, which will equal the sum of the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 variances of the expanded messages. The stretching and periodic extension (3) do not change the equal variance property, so it holds for the final check node messages. The variable nodes multiply dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 check node messages. Each Gaussian in the resulting mixture is a product of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 single Gaussians, one from each mixture, and the channel noise Gaussian. According to claim 2, they will all have the same variance. The final normalization step does not change the variances so the equal variance property is kept for the final variable node messages at iteration t+1ğ‘¡1t+1. âˆ

Until this point we did not impose any restrictions on the LDLC. From now on, we shall restrict ourselves to magic square regular LDLC (see Definition 3). The basic iterative equations that relate the variances at iteration t+1ğ‘¡1t+1 to the variances at iteration tğ‘¡t are summarized in the following two lemmas.

Lemma 3

For magic square LDLC, variable node messages that are sent at the same iteration along edges with the same absolute value have the same variance.

Proof:

See Appendix D. âˆ

Lemma 4

For magic square LDLC with degree dğ‘‘d, denote the variance of the messages that are sent at iteration tğ‘¡t along edges with weight Â±hlplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘™\pm h_{l} by Vl(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘™V^{(t)}_{l}. The variance values V1(t),V2(t),â€¦,Vd(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘‘V^{(t)}_{1},V^{(t)}_{2},...,V^{(t)}_{d} obey the following recursion:

1Vi(t+1)=1Ïƒ2+âˆ‘m=1mâ‰ idhm2âˆ‘j=1jâ‰ mdhj2â€‹Vj(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘š2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘šğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—\displaystyle\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}m=1\\ m\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{h_{m}^{2}}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq m\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{j}^{2}V^{(t)}_{j}} (4)

for i=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...d, with initial conditions V1(0)=V2(0)=â€¦=Vd(0)=Ïƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰01subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰02â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰0ğ‘‘superscriptğœ2V^{(0)}_{1}=V^{(0)}_{2}=...=V^{(0)}_{d}=\sigma^{2}.

Proof:

See Appendix D. âˆ

For illustration, the recursion for the case d=3ğ‘‘3d=3 is:

1V1(t+1)=h22h12â€‹V1(t)+h32â€‹V3(t)+h32h12â€‹V1(t)+h22â€‹V2(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡11superscriptsubscriptâ„22superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡3superscriptsubscriptâ„32superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡21superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{1}}=\frac{h_{2}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}V^{(t)}_{1}+h_{3}^{2}V^{(t)}_{3}}+\frac{h_{3}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}V^{(t)}_{1}+h_{2}^{2}V^{(t)}_{2}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}} (5)
1V2(t+1)=h12h22â€‹V2(t)+h32â€‹V3(t)+h32h12â€‹V1(t)+h22â€‹V2(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡12superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡3superscriptsubscriptâ„32superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡21superscriptğœ2\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{2}}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{2}^{2}V^{(t)}_{2}+h_{3}^{2}V^{(t)}_{3}}+\frac{h_{3}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}V^{(t)}_{1}+h_{2}^{2}V^{(t)}_{2}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}
1V3(t+1)=h12h22â€‹V2(t)+h32â€‹V3(t)+h22h12â€‹V1(t)+h32â€‹V3(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡13superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡3superscriptsubscriptâ„22superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡31superscriptğœ2\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{3}}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{2}^{2}V^{(t)}_{2}+h_{3}^{2}V^{(t)}_{3}}+\frac{h_{2}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}V^{(t)}_{1}+h_{3}^{2}V^{(t)}_{3}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}

The lemmas above are used to prove the following theorem regarding the convergence of the variances.

Theorem 1

For a magic square LDLC with degree dğ‘‘d and generating sequence h1â‰¥h2â‰¥â€¦â‰¥hd>0subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘0h_{1}\geq h_{2}\geq...\geq h_{d}>0, define Î±=Î”âˆ‘i=2dhi2h12superscriptÎ”ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptâ„12\alpha\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}. Assume that Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1. Then:

  1. 1.

    The first variance approaches a constant value of Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha), where Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the channel noise variance:

    V1(âˆ)=Î”limtâ†’âˆV1(t)=Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±).superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰1subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\displaystyle V^{(\infty)}_{1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}V^{(t)}_{1}=\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha).
  2. 2.

    The other variances approach zero:

    Vi(âˆ)=Î”limtâ†’âˆVi(t)=0superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–0\displaystyle V^{(\infty)}_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}V^{(t)}_{i}=0

    for i=2,3..di=2,3..d.

  3. 3.

    The asymptotic convergence rate of all variances is exponential:

    0<limtâ†’âˆ|Vi(t)âˆ’Vi(âˆ)Î±t|<âˆ0subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\displaystyle 0<\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\left|\frac{V^{(t)}_{i}-V^{(\infty)}_{i}}{\alpha^{t}}\right|<\infty

    for i=1,2..di=1,2..d.

  4. 4.

    The zero approaching variances are upper bounded by the decaying exponential Ïƒ2â€‹Î±tsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\sigma^{2}\alpha^{t}:

    Vi(t)â‰¤Ïƒ2â€‹Î±tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\displaystyle V^{(t)}_{i}\leq\sigma^{2}\alpha^{t}

    for i=2,3..di=2,3..d and tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0.

Proof:

See Appendix D. âˆ

If Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1, the variances may still converge, but convergence rate may be as slow as oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘œ1ğ‘¡o(1/t), as illustrated in Appendix D.

Convergence of the variances to zero implies that the Gaussians approach impulses. This is a desired property of the decoder, since the exact PDF that we want to calculate is indeed a weighted sum of impulses (see (1)). It can be seen that by designing a code with Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, i.e. h12>âˆ‘i=2dhi2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2h_{1}^{2}>\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}, one variance approaches a constant (and not zero). However, all the other variances approach zero, where all variances converge in an exponential rate. This will be the preferred mode because the information can be recovered even if a single variance does not decay to zero, where exponential convergence is certainly preferred over slow 1/t1ğ‘¡1/t convergence. Therefore, from now on we shall restrict our analysis to magic square LDLC with Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1.

Theorem 1 shows that every iteration, each variable node will generate dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages with variances that approach zero, and a single message with variance that approaches a constant. The message with nonzero variance will be transmitted along the edge with largest weight (i.e. h1subscriptâ„1h_{1}). However, from the derivation of Appendix D it can be seen that the opposite happens for the check nodes: each check node will generate dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages with variances that approach a constant, and a single message with variance that approaches zero. The check node message with zero approaching variance will be transmitted along the edge with largest weight.

IV-C Convergence of the Mean Values

The reason that the messages are mixtures and not single Gaussians lies in the periodic extension step (3) at the check nodes, and every Gaussian at the output of this step can be related to a single index of the infinite sum. Therefore, we can label each Gaussian at iteration tğ‘¡t with a list of all the indices that were used in (3) during its creation process in iterations 1,2,â€¦â€‹t12â€¦ğ‘¡1,2,...t.

Definition 4 (label of a Gaussian)

The label of a Gaussian consists of a sequence of triplets of the form {t,c,i}ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘–\{t,c,i\}, where tğ‘¡t is an iteration index, cğ‘c is a check node index and iğ‘–i is an integer. The labels are initialized to the empty sequence. Then, the labels are updated along each iteration according to the following update rules:

  1. 1.

    In the periodic extension step (3), each Gaussian in the output periodic mixture is assigned the label of the specific Gaussian of pjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥p_{j}(x) that generated it, concatenated with a single triplet {t,c,i}ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘–\{t,c,i\}, where tğ‘¡t is the current iteration index, cğ‘c is the check node index and iğ‘–i is the index in the infinite sum of (3) that corresponds to this Gaussian.

  2. 2.

    In the convolution step and the product step, each Gaussian in the output mixture is assigned a label that equals the concatenation of all the labels of the specific Gaussians in the input messages that formed this Gaussian.

  3. 3.

    The stretching and normalization steps do not alter the label of each Gaussian: Each Gaussian in the stretched/normalized mixture inherits the label of the appropriate Gaussian in the original mixture.

Definition 5 (a consistent Gaussian)

A Gaussian in a mixture is called â€œ[tasubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{a}, tbsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{b}] consistentâ€ if its label contains no contradictions for iterations tasubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{a} to tbsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{b}, i.e. for every pair of triplets {t1,c1,i1}subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘–1\{t_{1},c_{1},i_{1}\}, {t2,c2,i2}subscriptğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘–2\{t_{2},c_{2},i_{2}\} such that taâ‰¤t1,t2â‰¤tbformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{a}\leq t_{1},t_{2}\leq t_{b}, if c1=c2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2c_{1}=c_{2} then i1=i2subscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘–2i_{1}=i_{2}. A [00, âˆ\infty] consistent Gaussian will be simply called a consistent Gaussian.

We can relate every consistent Gaussian to a unique integer vector bÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nÂ¯ğ‘superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›\underline{b}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}, which holds the nğ‘›n integers used in the nğ‘›n check nodes. Since in the periodic extension step (3) the sum is taken over all integers, a consistent Gaussian exists in each variable node message for every possible integer valued vector bÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nÂ¯ğ‘superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›\underline{b}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}. We shall see later that this consistent Gaussian corresponds to the lattice point ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}.

According to Theorem 1, if we choose the nonzero values of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} such that Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, every variable node generates dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages with variances approaching zero and a single message with variance that approaches a constant. We shall refer to these messages as â€œnarrowâ€ messages and â€œwideâ€ messages, respectively. For a given integer valued vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, we shall concentrate on the consistent Gaussians that relate to bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in all the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd variable node messages that are generated in each iteration (a single Gaussian in each message). The following lemmas summarize the asymptotic behavior of the mean values of these consistent Gaussians for the narrow messages.

Lemma 5

For a magic square LDLC with degree dğ‘‘d and Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, consider the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow messages that are sent from a specific variable node. Consider further a single Gaussian in each message, which is the consistent Gaussian that relates to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. Asymptotically, the mean values of these dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 Gaussians become equal.

Proof:

See Appendix E. âˆ

Lemma 6

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree dğ‘‘d and Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, consider only consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} and belong to narrow messages. Denote the common mean value of the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 such Gaussians that are sent from variable node iğ‘–i at iteration tğ‘¡t by mi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–m^{(t)}_{i}, and arrange all these mean values in a column vector mÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡\underline{m}^{(t)} of dimension nğ‘›n. Define the error vector eÂ¯(t)=Î”mÂ¯(t)âˆ’xÂ¯superscriptÎ”superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{e}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{m}^{(t)}-\underline{x}, where xÂ¯=ğ†â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ†Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b} is the lattice point that corresponds to bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. Then, for large tğ‘¡t, eÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡\underline{e}^{(t)} satisfies:

eÂ¯(t+1)â‰ˆâˆ’ğ‘¯~â‹…eÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1â‹…~ğ‘¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}\approx-\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)} (6)

where ğ‡~~ğ‡\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is derived from ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H} by permuting the rows such that the Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} elements will be placed on the diagonal, dividing each row by the appropriate diagonal element (h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} or âˆ’h1subscriptâ„1-h_{1}), and then nullifying the diagonal.

Proof:

See Appendix E. âˆ

We can now state the following theorem, which describes the conditions for convergence and the steady state value of the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the narrow variable node messages.

Theorem 2

For a magic square LDLC with Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the narrow variable node messages that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} are assured to converge if and only if all the eigenvalues of ğ‡~~ğ‡\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} have magnitude less than 111, where ğ‡~~ğ‡\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Lemma 6. When this condition is fulfilled, the mean values converge to the coordinates of the appropriate lattice point: mÂ¯(âˆ)=ğ†â‹…bÂ¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šâ‹…ğ†Â¯ğ‘\underline{m}^{(\infty)}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}.

Proof:

Immediate from Lemma 6. âˆ

Note that without adding random signs to the LDLC nonzero values, the all-ones vector will be an eigenvector of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} with eigenvalue âˆ‘i=2dhih1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptâ„1\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}}{h_{1}}, which may exceed 111.

Interestingly, recursion (6) is also obeyed by the error of the Jacobi method for solving systems of sparse linear equations [22] (see also Section VIII-A), when it is used to solve ğ‘¯â€‹mÂ¯=bÂ¯ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘šÂ¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}\underline{m}=\underline{b} (with solution mÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘šğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{m}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}). Therefore, the LDLC decoder can be viewed as a superposition of Jacobi solvers, one for each possible value of the integer valued vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}.

We shall now turn to the convergence of the mean values of the wide messages. The asymptotic behavior is summarized in the following lemma.

Lemma 7

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n and Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, consider only consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} and belong to wide messages. Denote the mean value of such a Gaussian that is sent from variable node iğ‘–i at iteration tğ‘¡t by mi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–m^{(t)}_{i}, and arrange all these mean values in a column vector mÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡\underline{m}^{(t)} of dimension nğ‘›n. Define the error vector eÂ¯(t)=Î”mÂ¯(t)âˆ’ğ†â€‹bÂ¯superscriptÎ”superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ†Â¯ğ‘\underline{e}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{m}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Then, for large tğ‘¡t, eÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡\underline{e}^{(t)} satisfies:

eÂ¯(t+1)â‰ˆâˆ’ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯(t)+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(yÂ¯âˆ’ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1â‹…ğ‘­superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1ğ›¼Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}\approx-\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)}+(1-\alpha)(\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}) (7)

where yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} is the noisy codeword and ğ…ğ…\boldsymbol{F} is an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n matrix defined by:

Fk,l={Hr,kHr,lifÂ â€‹kâ‰ lâ€‹Â and there exist a rowÂ â€‹râ€‹Â of Hfor whichÂ â€‹|Hr,l|=h1â€‹Â andÂ â€‹Hr,kâ‰ 00otherwisesubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘™casessubscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘™ifÂ ğ‘˜ğ‘™Â and there exist a rowÂ ğ‘ŸÂ of Hmissing-subexpressionfor whichÂ subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘™subscriptâ„1Â andÂ subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜00otherwise\displaystyle F_{k,l}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{H_{r,k}}{H_{r,l}}&\textrm{if }k\neq l\textrm{ and there exist a row }r\textrm{ of H}\\ &\textrm{for which }|H_{r,l}|=h_{1}\textrm{ and }H_{r,k}\neq 0\\ 0&\textrm{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (11)
Proof:

See Appendix E, where an alternative way to construct ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} from ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is also presented. âˆ

The conditions for convergence and steady state solution for the wide messages are described in the following theorem.

Theorem 3

For a magic square LDLC with Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, the mean values of the consistent Gaussians of the wide variable node messages that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} are assured to converge if and only if all the eigenvalues of ğ…ğ…\boldsymbol{F} have magnitude less than 111, where ğ…ğ…\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Lemma 7. When this condition is fulfilled, the steady state solution is mÂ¯(âˆ)=ğ†â‹…bÂ¯+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğˆ+ğ…)âˆ’1â€‹(yÂ¯âˆ’ğ†â‹…bÂ¯)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šâ‹…ğ†Â¯ğ‘1ğ›¼superscriptğˆğ…1Â¯ğ‘¦â‹…ğ†Â¯ğ‘\underline{m}^{(\infty)}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}+(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}(\underline{y}-\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}).

Proof:

Immediate from Lemma 7. âˆ

Unlike the narrow messages, the mean values of the wide messages do not converge to the appropriate lattice point coordinates. The steady state error depends on the difference between the noisy observation and the lattice point, as well as on Î±ğ›¼\alpha, and it decreases to zero as Î±â†’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\rightarrow 1. Note that the final PDF of a variable is generated by multiplying all the dğ‘‘d check node messages that arrive to the appropriate variable node. dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 of these messages are wide, and therefore their mean values have a steady state error. One message is narrow, so it converges to an impulse at the lattice point coordinate. Therefore, the final product will be an impulse at the correct location, where the wide messages will only affect the magnitude of this impulse. As long as the mean values errors are not too large (relative to the width of the wide messages), this should not cause an impulse that corresponds to a wrong lattice point to have larger amplitude than the correct one. However, for large noise, these steady state errors may cause the decoder to deviate from the ML solution (As explained in Section IV-D).

To summarize the results for the mean values, we considered the mean values of all the consistent Gaussians that correspond to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. A single Gaussian of this form exists in each of the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd variable node messages that are generated in each iteration. For each variable node, dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages are narrow (have variance that approaches zero) and a single message is wide (variance approaches a constant). Under certain conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of all the narrow messages converge to the appropriate coordinate of the lattice point ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Under additional conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of the wide messages converge, but the steady state values contain an error term.

We analyzed the behavior of consistent Gaussian. It should be noted that there are many more non-consistent Gaussians. Furthermore non-consistent Gaussians are generated in each iteration for any existing consistent Gaussian. We conjecture that unless a Gaussian is consistent, or becomes consistent along the iterations, it fades out, at least at noise conditions where the algorithm converges. The reason is that non-consistency in the integer values leads to mismatch in the corresponding PDFâ€™s, and so the amplitude of that Gaussian is attenuated.

We considered consistent Gaussians which correspond to a specific integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, but such a set of Gaussians exists for every possible choice of bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, i.e. for every lattice point. Therefore, the narrow messages will converge to a solution that has an impulse at the appropriate coordinate of every lattice point. This resembles the exact solution (1), so the key for proper convergence lies in the amplitudes: we would like the consistent Gaussians of the ML lattice point to have the largest amplitude for each message.

IV-D Convergence of the Amplitudes

We shall now analyze the behavior of the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians (as discussed later, this is not enough for complete convergence analysis, but it certainly gives insight to the nature of the convergence process and its properties). The behavior of the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians is summarized in the following lemma.

Lemma 8

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree dğ‘‘d and Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, consider the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration tğ‘¡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹nâ€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘›ğ‘‘i=1,2,...nd, and define the log-amplitude as li(t)=logâ¡pi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–l^{(t)}_{i}=\log p^{(t)}_{i}. Arrange these nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd log-amplitudes in a column vector lÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘¡\underline{l}^{(t)}, such that element (kâˆ’1)â€‹d+iğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–(k-1)d+i corresponds to the message that is sent from variable node kğ‘˜k along an edge with weight Â±hiplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘–\pm h_{i}. Assume further that the bipartite graph of the LDLC contains no 4-loops. Then, the log-amplitudes satisfy the following recursion:

lÂ¯(t+1)=ğ‘¨â‹…lÂ¯(t)âˆ’aÂ¯(t)âˆ’cÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘¡1â‹…ğ‘¨superscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle\underline{l}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{A}\cdot\underline{l}^{(t)}-\underline{a}^{(t)}-\underline{c}^{(t)} (12)

with initialization lÂ¯(0)=0Â¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘™0Â¯0\underline{l}^{(0)}=\underline{0}. ğ€ğ€\boldsymbol{A} is an nâ€‹dÃ—nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘nd\times nd matrix which is all zeros except exactly (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} â€™111â€™s in each row and each column. The element of the excitation vector aÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{a}^{(t)} at location (kâˆ’1)â€‹d+iğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–(k-1)d+i (where k=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘˜12â€¦ğ‘›k=1,2,...n and i=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...d) equals:

a(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)=subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–absent\displaystyle a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}= (13)
=V^k,i(t)2â€‹(âˆ‘l=1lâ‰ idâˆ‘j=l+1jâ‰ id(m~k,l(t)âˆ’m~k,j(t))2V~k,l(t)â‹…V~k,j(t)+âˆ‘l=1lâ‰ id(m~k,l(t)âˆ’yk)2Ïƒ2â‹…V~k,l(t))absentsubscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘™1ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—2â‹…subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜2â‹…superscriptğœ2subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™\displaystyle=\frac{\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}}{2}\left(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=l+1\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,l}-\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,j}\right)^{2}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l}\cdot\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,l}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\sigma^{2}\cdot\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l}}\right)

where m~k,l(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,l} and V~k,l(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l} denote the mean value and variance of the consistent Gaussian that relates to the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in the check node message that arrives to variable node kğ‘˜k at iteration tğ‘¡t along an edge with weight Â±hlplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘™\pm h_{l}. yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k} is the noisy channel observation of variable node kğ‘˜k, and V^k,i(t)=Î”(1Ïƒ2+âˆ‘l=1lâ‰ id1V~k,l(t))âˆ’1superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–superscript1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘‘1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™1\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\left(\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}l=1\\ l\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{1}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,l}}\right)^{-1}. Finally, cÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{c}^{(t)} is a constant excitation term that is independent of the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} (i.e. is the same for all consistent Gaussians). Note that an iteration is defined as sending variable node messages, followed by sending check node messages. The first iteration (where the variable nodes send the initialization PDF) is regarded as iteration 00.

Proof:

At the check node, the amplitude of a Gaussian at the convolution output is the product of the amplitudes of the corresponding Gaussians in the appropriate variable node messages. At the variable node, the amplitude of a Gaussian at the product output is the product of the amplitudes of the corresponding Gaussians in the appropriate check node messages, multiplied by the Gaussian scaling term, according to claim 2. Since we assume that the bipartite graph of the LDLC contains no 4-loops, an amplitude of a variable node message at iteration tğ‘¡t will therefore equal the product of (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} amplitudes of Gaussians of variable node messages from iteration tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1, multiplied by the Gaussian scaling term. This proves (12) and shows that Ağ´A has (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} â€™1â€™s in every row. However, since each variable node message affects exactly (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} variable node messages of the next iteration, Ağ´A must also have (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} â€™1â€™s in every column. The total excitation term âˆ’aÂ¯(t)âˆ’cÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡-\underline{a}^{(t)}-\underline{c}^{(t)} corresponds to the logarithm of the Gaussian scaling term. Each element of this scaling term results from the product of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 check node Gaussians and the channel Gaussian, according to claim 2. This scaling term sums over all the pairs of Gaussians, and in (13) the sum is separated to pairs that include the channel Gaussian and pairs that do not. The total excitation is divided between (13), which depends on the choice of the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, and cÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{c}^{(t)}, which includes all the constant terms that are independent on bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} (including the normalization operation which is performed at the variable node). âˆ

Since there are exactly (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2} â€™111â€™s in each column of the matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨\boldsymbol{A}, it is easy to see that the all-ones vector is an eigenvector of ğ‘¨ğ‘¨\boldsymbol{A}, with eigenvalue (dâˆ’1)2superscriptğ‘‘12(d-1)^{2}. If d>2ğ‘‘2d>2, this eigenvalue is larger than 111, meaning that the recursion (12) is non-stable.

It can be seen that the excitation term aÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{a}^{(t)} has two components. The first term sums the squared differences between the mean values of all the possible pairs of received check node messages (weighted by the inverse product of the appropriate variances). It therefore measures the mismatch between the incoming messages. This mismatch will be small if the mean values of the consistent Gaussians converge to the coordinates of a lattice point (any lattice point). The second term sums the squared differences between the mean values of the incoming messages and the noisy channel output yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k}. This term measures the mismatch between the incoming messages and the channel measurement. It will be smallest if the mean values of the consistent Gaussians converge to the coordinates of the ML lattice point.

The following lemma summarizes some properties of the excitation term aÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{a}^{(t)}.

Lemma 9

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree dğ‘‘d, Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the consistent Gaussians that correspond to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. According to Lemma 8, their amplitudes satisfy recursion (12). The excitation term aÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{a}^{(t)} of (12), which is defined by (13), satisfies the following properties:

  1. 1.

    ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i}, the iğ‘–iâ€™th element of aÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘¡\underline{a}^{(t)}, is non-negative, finite and bounded for every iğ‘–i and every tğ‘¡t. Moreover, ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} converges to a finite non-negative steady state value as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\rightarrow\infty.

  2. 2.

    limtâ†’âˆâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)=12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–12superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i}=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword and ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} is a positive definite matrix defined by:

    ğ‘¾=Î”(d+1âˆ’Î±)â€‹ğ‘°âˆ’2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1+superscriptÎ”ğ‘¾ğ‘‘1ğ›¼ğ‘°limit-from21ğ›¼superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{W}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(d+1-\alpha)\boldsymbol{I}-2(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}+ (14)
    +(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1Tâ€‹((dâˆ’1)2â€‹ğ‘°âˆ’ğ‘­Tâ€‹ğ‘­)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’11ğ›¼superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­superscript1ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘°superscriptğ‘­ğ‘‡ğ‘­superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­1\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{{-1}^{T}}\left((d-1)^{2}\boldsymbol{I}-\boldsymbol{F}^{T}\boldsymbol{F}\right)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}

    where ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Lemma 7.

  3. 3.

    For an LDLC with degree d>2ğ‘‘2d>2, the weighted infinite sum âˆ‘j=0âˆâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(j)(dâˆ’1)2â€‹j+2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘—2\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}} converges to a finite value.

Proof:

See Appendix F. âˆ

The following theorem addresses the question of which consistent Gaussian will have the maximal asymptotic amplitude. We shall first consider the case of an LDLC with degree d>2ğ‘‘2d>2, and then consider the special case of d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 in a separate theorem.

Theorem 4

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree d>2ğ‘‘2d>2, Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration tğ‘¡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹nâ€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘›ğ‘‘i=1,2,...nd, and define the product-of-amplitudes as P(t)=Î”âˆi=1nâ€‹dpi(t)superscriptÎ”superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–P^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\prod_{i=1}^{nd}p^{(t)}_{i}. Define further S=âˆ‘j=0âˆâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(j)(dâˆ’1)2â€‹j+2ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘—2S=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}}, where ai(j)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–a^{(j)}_{i} is defined by (13) (Sğ‘†S is well defined according to Lemma 9). Then:

  1. 1.

    The integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} for which the consistent Gaussians will have the largest asymptotic product-of-amplitudes limtâ†’âˆP(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}P^{(t)} is the one for which Sğ‘†S is minimized.

  2. 2.

    The product-of-amplitudes for the consistent Gaussians that correspond to all other integer vectors will decay to zero in a super-exponential rate.

Proof:

As in Lemma 8, define the log-amplitudes li(t)=Î”logâ¡pi(t)superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–l^{(t)}_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\log p^{(t)}_{i}. Define further s(t)=Î”âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dli(t)superscriptÎ”superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘–s^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}l^{(t)}_{i}. Taking the element-wise sum of (12), we get:

s(t+1)=(dâˆ’1)2â€‹s(t)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘‘12superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle s^{(t+1)}=(d-1)^{2}s^{(t)}-\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} (15)

with initialization s(0)=0superscriptğ‘ 00s^{(0)}=0. Note that we ignored the term âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dci(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{nd}c^{(t)}_{i}. As shown below, we are looking for the vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that maximizes s(t)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s^{(t)}. Since (15) is a linear difference equation, and the term âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dci(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{nd}c^{(t)}_{i} is independent of bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, its effect on s(t)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s^{(t)} is common to all bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} and is therefore not interesting.

Define now s~(t)=Î”s(t)(dâˆ’1)2â€‹tsuperscriptÎ”superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡\tilde{s}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{s^{(t)}}{(d-1)^{2t}}. Substituting in (15), we get:

s~(t+1)=s~(t)âˆ’1(dâˆ’1)2â€‹t+2â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡1superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{s}^{(t+1)}=\tilde{s}^{(t)}-\frac{1}{(d-1)^{2t+2}}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} (16)

with initialization s~(0)=0superscript~ğ‘ 00\tilde{s}^{(0)}=0, which can be solved to get:

s~(t)=âˆ’âˆ‘j=0tâˆ’1âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(j)(dâˆ’1)2â€‹j+2superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘—2\displaystyle\tilde{s}^{(t)}=-\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}} (17)

We would now like to compare the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians with various values of the corresponding integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in order to find the lattice point whose consistent Gaussians will have largest product-of-amplitudes. From the definitions of s(t)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s^{(t)} and s~(t)superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡\tilde{s}^{(t)} we then have:

P(t)=es(t)=e(dâˆ’1)2â€‹tâ‹…s~(t)superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’â‹…superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡\displaystyle P^{(t)}=e^{s^{(t)}}=e^{(d-1)^{2t}\cdot\tilde{s}^{(t)}} (18)

Consider two integer vectors bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that relate to two lattice points. Denote the corresponding product-of-amplitudes by P0(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ‘¡P_{0}^{(t)} and P1(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ‘¡P_{1}^{(t)}, respectively, and assume that for these two vectors Sğ‘†S converges to the values S0subscriptğ‘†0S_{0} and S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1}, respectively. Then, taking into account that limtâ†’âˆs~(t)=âˆ’Ssubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscript~ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘†\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\tilde{s}^{(t)}=-S, the asymptotic ratio of the product-of-amplitudes for these lattice points will be:

limtâ†’âˆP1(t)P0(t)=eâˆ’(dâˆ’1)2â€‹tâ‹…S1eâˆ’(dâˆ’1)2â€‹tâ‹…S0=e(dâˆ’1)2â€‹tâ‹…(S0âˆ’S1)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’â‹…superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†1superscriptğ‘’â‹…superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†0superscriptğ‘’â‹…superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†0subscriptğ‘†1\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{P_{1}^{(t)}}{P_{0}^{(t)}}=\frac{e^{-(d-1)^{2t}\cdot S_{1}}}{e^{-(d-1)^{2t}\cdot S_{0}}}=e^{(d-1)^{2t}\cdot(S_{0}-S_{1})} (19)

It can be seen that if S0<S1subscriptğ‘†0subscriptğ‘†1S_{0}<S_{1}, the ratio decreases to zero in a super exponential rate. This shows that the lattice point for which Sğ‘†S is minimized will have the largest product-of-amplitudes, where for all other lattice points, the product-of-amplitudes will decay to zero in a super-exponential rate (recall that the normalization operation at the variable node keeps the sum of all amplitudes in a message to be 1). This completes the proof of the theorem. âˆ

We now have to find which integer valued vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} minimizes Sğ‘†S. The analysis is difficult because the weighting factor inside the sum of (17) performs exponential weighting of the excitation terms, where the dominant terms are those of the first iterations. Therefore, we can not use the asymptotic results of Lemma 9, but have to analyze the transient behavior. However, the analysis is simpler for the case of an LDLC with row and column degree of d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, so we shall first turn to this simple case (note that for this case, both the convolution in the check nodes and the product at the variable nodes involve only a single message).

Theorem 5

For a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1 and no 4-loops, consider the 2â€‹n2ğ‘›2n consistent Gaussians that relate to a given integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} in the variable node messages that are sent at iteration tğ‘¡t (one consistent Gaussian per message). Denote the amplitudes of these Gaussians by pi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–p^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹2â€‹nğ‘–12â€¦2ğ‘›i=1,2,...2n, and define the product-of-amplitudes as P(t)=Î”âˆi=12â€‹npi(t)superscriptÎ”superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–12ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–P^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\prod_{i=1}^{2n}p^{(t)}_{i}. Then:

  1. 1.

    The integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} for which the consistent Gaussians will have the largest asymptotic product-of-amplitudes limtâ†’âˆP(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}P^{(t)} is the one for which (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) is minimized, where ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} is defined by (14) and yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword.

  2. 2.

    The product-of-amplitudes for the consistent Gaussians that correspond to all other integer vectors will decay to zero in an exponential rate.

Proof:

For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 (15) becomes:

s(t+1)=s(t)âˆ’âˆ‘i=12â€‹nai(t)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–12ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle s^{(t+1)}=s^{(t)}-\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(t)}_{i} (20)

With solution:

s(t)=âˆ’âˆ‘j=0tâˆ’1âˆ‘i=12â€‹nai(j)superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–12ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–\displaystyle s^{(t)}=-\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i} (21)

Denote Sa=limjâ†’âˆâˆ‘i=12â€‹nai(j)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptâ†’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–12ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–S_{a}=\lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i}. Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a} is well defined according to Lemma 9. For large tğ‘¡t, we then have s(t)â‰ˆâˆ’tâ‹…Sasuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†ğ‘s^{(t)}\approx-t\cdot S_{a}. Therefore, for two lattice points with excitation sum terms which approach Saâ€‹0,Saâ€‹1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘1S_{a0},S_{a1}, respectively, the ratio of the corresponding product-of-amplitudes will approach

limtâ†’âˆP1(t)P0(t)=eâˆ’Saâ€‹1â‹…teâˆ’Saâ€‹0â‹…t=e(Saâ€‹0âˆ’Saâ€‹1)â‹…tsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’â‹…subscriptğ‘†ğ‘1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’â‹…subscriptğ‘†ğ‘0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’â‹…subscriptğ‘†ğ‘0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘1ğ‘¡\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{P_{1}^{(t)}}{P_{0}^{(t)}}=\frac{e^{-S_{a1}\cdot t}}{e^{-S_{a0}\cdot t}}=e^{(S_{a0}-S_{a1})\cdot t} (22)

If Saâ€‹0<Saâ€‹1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘1S_{a0}<S_{a1}, the ratio decreases to zero exponentially (unlike the case of d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 where the rate was super-exponential, as in (19)). This shows that the lattice point for which Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a} is minimized will have the largest product-of-amplitudes, where for all other lattice points, the product-of-amplitudes will decay to zero in an exponential rate (recall that the normalization operation at the variable node keeps the sum of all amplitudes in a message to be 1). This completes the proof of the second part of the theorem.

We still have to find the vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that minimizes Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a}. The basic difference between the case of d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 and the case of d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 is that for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 we need to analyze the transient behavior of the excitation terms, where for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 we only need to analyze the asymptotic behavior, which is much easier to handle.

According to Lemma 9, we have:

Sa=Î”limjâ†’âˆâˆ‘i=12â€‹nai(j)=12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptâ†’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–12ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–12superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle S_{a}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{2n}a^{(j)}_{i}=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) (23)

where ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} is defined by (14) and yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} is the noisy received codeword. Therefore, for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, the lattice points whose consistent Gaussians will have largest product-of-amplitudes is the point for which (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) is minimized. This completes the proof of the theorem. âˆ

For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 we could find an explicit expression for the â€œwinningâ€ lattice point.
