As discussed above, we could not find an explicit expression for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2, since the result depends on the transient behavior of the excitation sum term, and not only on the steady state value. However, a reasonable conjecture is to assume that bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that maximizes the steady state excitation will also maximize the term that depends on the transient behavior. This means that a reasonable conjecture is to assume that the â€œwinningâ€ lattice point for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 will also minimize an expression of the form (23).

Note that for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 we can still show that for â€œweakâ€ noise, the ML point will have the minimal Sğ‘†S. To see that, it comes out from (13) that for zero noise, the ML lattice point will have ai(t)=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–0a^{(t)}_{i}=0 for every tğ‘¡t and iğ‘–i, where all other lattice points will have ai(t)>0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–0a^{(t)}_{i}>0 for at least some iğ‘–i and tğ‘¡t. Therefore, the ML point will have a minimal excitation term along the transient behavior so it will surely have the minimal Sğ‘†S and the best product-of-amplitudes. As the noise increases, it is difficult to analyze the transient behavior of ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i}, as discussed above.

Note that the ML solution minimizes (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where the above analysis yields minimization of (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}). Obviously, for zero noise (i.e. yÂ¯=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{y}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\ \underline{b}) both minimizations will give the correct solution with zero score. As the noise increases, the solutions may deviate from one another. Therefore, both minimizations will give the same solution for â€œweakâ€ noise but may give different solutions for â€œstrongâ€ noise.

An example for another decoder that performs this form of minimization is the linear detector, which calculates bÂ¯^=âŒŠğ‘¯â‹…yÂ¯âŒ‰\hat{\underline{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{y}\right\rceil (where âŒŠxâŒ‰delimited-âŒŠâŒ‰ğ‘¥\left\lfloor x\right\rceil denotes the nearest integer to xğ‘¥x). This is equivalent to minimizing (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}) with ğ‘¾=ğ‘¯Tâ€‹ğ‘¯=ğ‘®âˆ’1Tâ€‹ğ‘®âˆ’1ğ‘¾superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘‡ğ‘¯superscriptğ‘®superscript1ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘®1\boldsymbol{W}=\boldsymbol{H}^{T}\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{G}^{{-1}^{T}}\boldsymbol{G}^{-1}. The linear detector fails to yield the ML solution if the noise is too strong, due to its inherent noise amplification.

For the LDLC iterative decoder, we would like that the deviation from the ML decoder due to the ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} matrix would be negligible in the expected range of noise variance. Experimental results (see Section IX) show that the iterative decoder indeed converges to the ML solution for noise variance values that approach channel capacity. However, for quantization or shaping applications (see Section VIII-B), where the effective noise is uniformly distributed along the Voronoi cell of the lattice (and is much stronger than the noise variance at channel capacity) the iterative decoder fails, and this can be explained by the influence of the ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} matrix on the minimization, as described above. Note from (14) that as Î±â†’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\rightarrow 1, ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} approaches a scaled identity matrix, which means that the minimization criterion approaches the ML criterion. However, the variances converge as Î±tsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha^{t}, so as Î±â†’1â†’ğ›¼1\alpha\rightarrow 1 convergence time approaches infinity.

Until this point, we concentrated only on consistent Gaussians, and checked what lattice point maximizes the product-of-amplitudes of all the corresponding consistent Gaussians. However, this approach does not necessarily lead to the lattice point that will be finally chosen by the decoder, due to 3 main reasons:

  1. 1.

    It comes out experimentally that the strongest Gaussian in each message is not necessarily a consistent Gaussian, but a Gaussian that started as non-consistent and became consistent at a certain iteration. Such a Gaussian will finally converge to the appropriate lattice point, since the convergence of the mean values is independent of initial conditions. The non-consistency at the first several iterations, where the mean values are still very noisy, allows these Gaussians to accumulate stronger amplitudes than the consistent Gaussians (recall that the exponential weighting in (17) for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 results in strong dependency on the behavior at the first iterations).

  2. 2.

    There is an exponential number of Gaussians that start as non-consistent and become consistent (with the same integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}) at a certain iteration, and the final amplitude of the Gaussians at the lattice point coordinates will be determined by the sum of all these Gaussians.

  3. 3.

    We ignored non-consistent Gaussians that endlessly remain non-consistent. We have not shown it analytically, but it is reasonable to assume that the excitation terms for such Gaussians will be weaker than for Gaussians that become consistent at some point, so their amplitude will fade away to zero. However, non-consistent Gaussians are born every iteration, even at steady state. The â€œnewly-bornâ€ non-consistent Gaussians may appear as sidelobes to the main impulse, since it may take several iterations until they are attenuated. Proper choice of the coefficients of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} may minimize this effect, as discussed in Sections III-A and V-A. However, these Gaussians may be a problem for small dğ‘‘d (e.g. d=2ğ‘‘2d=2) where the product step at the variable node does not include enough messages to suppress them.

Note that the first two issues are not a problem for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2, where the winning lattice point depends only on the asymptotic behavior. The amplitude of a sum of Gaussians that converged to the same coordinates will still be governed by (21) and the winning lattice point will still minimize (23). The third issue is a problem for small dğ‘‘d, but less problematic for large dğ‘‘d, as described above.

As a result, we can not regard the convergence analysis of the consistent Gaussiansâ€™ amplitudes as a complete convergence analysis. However, it can certainly be used as a qualitative analysis that gives certain insights to the convergence process. Two main observations are:

  1. 1.

    The narrow variable node messages tend to converge to single impulses at the coordinates of a single lattice point. This results from (19), (22), which show that the â€œnon-winningâ€ consistent Gaussians will have amplitudes that decrease to zero relative to the amplitude of the â€œwinningâ€ consistent Gaussian. This result remains valid for the sum of non-consistent Gaussians that became consistent at a certain point, because it results from the non-stable nature of the recursion (12), which makes strong Gaussians stronger in an exponential manner. The single impulse might be accompanied by weak â€œsidelobesâ€ due to newly-born non-consistent Gaussians.

    Interestingly, this form of solution is different from the exact solution (1), where every lattice point is represented by an impulse at the appropriate coordinate, with amplitude that depends on the Euclidean distance of the lattice point from the observation. The iterative decoderâ€™s solution has a single impulse that corresponds to a single lattice point, where all other impulses have amplitudes that decay to zero. This should not be a problem, as long as the ML point is the remaining point (see discussion above).

  2. 2.

    We have shown that for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 the strongest consistent Gaussians relate to bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that minimizes an expression of the form (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}). We proposed a conjecture that this is also true for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2. We can further widen the conjecture to say that the finally decoded bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} (and not only the bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that relates to strongest consistent Gaussians) minimizes such an expression. Such a conjecture can explain why the iterative decoder works well for decoding near channel capacity, but fails for quantization or shaping, where the effective noise variance is much larger.

IV-E Summary of Convergence Results

To summarize the convergence analysis, it was first shown that the variable node messages are Gaussian mixtures. Therefore, it is sufficient to analyze the sequences of variances, mean values and relative amplitudes of the Gaussians in each mixture. Starting with the variances, it was shown that with proper choice of the magic square LDLC generating sequence, each variable node generates dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 â€œnarrowâ€ messages, whose variance decreases exponentially to zero, and a single â€œwideâ€ message, whose variance reaches a finite value. Consistent Gaussians were then defined as Gaussians that their generation process always involved the same integer at the same check node. Consistent Gaussians can then be related to an integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} or equivalently to the lattice point ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. It was then shown that under appropriate conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, the mean values of consistent Gaussians that belong to narrow messages converge to the coordinates of the appropriate lattice point. The mean values of wide messages also converge to these coordinates, but with a steady state error. Then, the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians were analyzed. For d=2ğ‘‘2d=2 it was shown that the consistent Gaussians with maximal product-of-amplitudes (over all messages) are those that correspond to an integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} than minimizes (ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}), where ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} is a positive definite matrix that depends only on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}. The product-of-amplitudes for all other consistent Gaussians decays to zero. For d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 the analysis is complex and depends on the transient behavior of the mean values and variances (and not only on their steady state values), but a reasonable conjecture is to assume that a same form of criterion is also minimized for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2. The result is different from the ML lattice point, which minimizes â€–ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯â€–2superscriptnormâ‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦2\left\|\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}-\underline{y}\right\|^{2}, where both criteria give the same point for weak noise but may give different solutions for strong noise. This may explain the experiments where the iterative decoder is successful in decoding the ML point for the AWGN channel near channel capacity, but fails in quantization or shaping applications where the effective noise is much stronger. These results also show that the iterative decoder converges to impulses at the coordinates of a single lattice point. It was then explained that analyzing the amplitudes of consistent Gaussians is not sufficient, so these results can not be regarded as a complete convergence analysis. However, the analysis gave a set of necessary conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, and also led to useful insights to the convergence process.

V Code Design

V-A Choosing the Generating Sequence

We shall concentrate on magic square LDLC, since they have inherent diversity of the nonzero elements in each row and column, which was shown above to be beneficial. It still remains to choose the LDLC generating sequence h1,h2,â€¦â€‹hdsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}. Assume that the algorithm converged, and each PDF has a peak at the desired value. When the periodic functions are multiplied at a variable node, the correct peaks will then align. We would like that all the other peaks will be strongly attenuated, i.e. there will be no other point where the peaks align. This resembles the definition of the least common multiple (LCM) of integers: if the periods were integers, we would like to have their LCM as large as possible. This argument suggests the sequence {1/2,1/3,1/5,1/7,1/11,1/13,1/17,â€¦}12131517111113117â€¦\{1/2,1/3,1/5,1/7,1/11,1/13,1/17,...\}, i.e. the reciprocals of the smallest dğ‘‘d prime numbers. Since the periods are 1/h1,1/h2,â€¦â€‹1/hd1subscriptâ„11subscriptâ„2â€¦1subscriptâ„ğ‘‘1/h_{1},1/h_{2},...1/h_{d}, we will get the desired property. Simulations have shown that increasing dğ‘‘d beyond 777 with this choice gave negligible improvement. Also, performance was improved by adding some â€œditherâ€ to the sequence, resulting in {1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55}12.3113.1715.1117.33111.71113.11117.55\{1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55\}. For d<7ğ‘‘7d<7, the first dğ‘‘d elements are used.

An alternative approach is a sequence of the form {1,Ïµ,Ïµ,â€¦,Ïµ}1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµâ€¦italic-Ïµ\{1,\epsilon,\epsilon,...,\epsilon\}, where Ïµ<<1much-less-thanitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon<<1. For this case, every variable node will receive a single message with period 111 and dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages with period 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon. For small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the period of these dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 messages will be large and multiplication by the channel Gaussian will attenuate all the unwanted replicas. The single remaining replica will attenuate all the unwanted replicas of the message with period 1. A convenient choice is Ïµ=1ditalic-Ïµ1ğ‘‘\epsilon=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}, which ensures that Î±=dâˆ’1d<1ğ›¼ğ‘‘1ğ‘‘1\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}<1, as required by Theorem 1. As an example, for d=7ğ‘‘7d=7 the sequence will be {1,17,17,17,17,17,17}1171717171717\{1,\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}}\}.

V-B Necessary Conditions on ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H}

The magic square LDLC definition and convergence analysis imply four necessary conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}:

  1. 1.

    |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|=1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=1. This condition is part of the LDLC definition, which ensures proper density of the lattice points in â„msuperscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathbb{R}^{m}. If |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|â‰ 1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|\neq 1, it can be easily normalized by dividing ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} by |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|nğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}. Note that practically we can allow |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|â‰ 1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1|det(\boldsymbol{H})|\neq 1 as long as |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|nâ‰ˆ1ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}\approx 1, since |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|nğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|} is the gain factor of the transmitted codeword. For example, if n=1000ğ‘›1000n=1000, having |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|=0.01ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯0.01|det(\boldsymbol{H})|=0.01 is acceptable, since we have |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|n=0.995ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯0.995\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}=0.995, which means that the codeword has to be further amplified by 20â‹…log10â¡(0.995)=0.04â‹…20subscript100.9950.0420\cdot\log_{10}(0.995)=0.04 dB, which is negligible.

    Note that normalizing ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is applicable only if ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is non-singular. If ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is singular, a row and a column should be sequentially omitted until ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} becomes full rank. This process may result in slightly reducing nğ‘›n and a slightly different row and column degrees than originally planned.

  2. 2.

    Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, where Î±=Î”âˆ‘i=2dhi2h12superscriptÎ”ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptâ„12\alpha\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}. This guarantees exponential convergence rate for the variances (Theorem 1). Choosing a smaller Î±ğ›¼\alpha results in faster convergence, but we should not take Î±ğ›¼\alpha too small since the steady state variance of the wide variable node messages, as well as the steady state error of the mean values of these messages, increases when Î±ğ›¼\alpha decreases, as discussed in Section IV-C. This may result in deviation of the decoded codeword from the ML codeword, as discussed in Section IV-D. For the first LDLC generating sequence of the previous subsection, we have Î±=0.92ğ›¼0.92\alpha=0.92 and 0.870.870.87 for d=7ğ‘‘7d=7 and 555, respectively, which is a reasonable trade off. For the second sequence type we have Î±=dâˆ’1dğ›¼ğ‘‘1ğ‘‘\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}.

  3. 3.

    All the eigenvalues of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} must have magnitude less than 111, where ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Theorem 2. This is a necessary condition for convergence of the mean values of the narrow messages. Note that adding random signs to the nonzero ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} elements is essential to fulfill this necessary condition, as explained in Section IV-C.

  4. 4.

    All the eigenvalues of ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} must have magnitude less than 111, where ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Theorem 3. This is a necessary condition for convergence of the mean values of the wide messages.

Interestingly, it comes out experimentally that for large codeword length nğ‘›n and relatively small degree dğ‘‘d (e.g. nâ‰¥1000ğ‘›1000n\geq 1000 and dâ‰¤10ğ‘‘10d\leq 10), a magic square LDLC with generating sequence that satisfies h1=1subscriptâ„11h_{1}=1 and Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1 results in ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} that satisfies all these four conditions: ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is nonsingular without any need to omit rows and columns, |dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)|nâ‰ˆ1ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1\sqrt[n]{|det(\boldsymbol{H})|}\approx 1 without any need for normalization, and all eigenvalues of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} and ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} have magnitude less than 1 (typically, the largest eigenvalue of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} or ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} has magnitude of 0.94âˆ’0.970.940.970.94-0.97, almost independently of nğ‘›n and the choice of nonzero ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} locations). Therefore, by simply dividing the first generating sequence of the previous subsection by its first element, the constructed ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} meets all the necessary conditions, where the second type of sequence meets the conditions without any need for modifications.

V-C Construction of ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H} for Magic Square LDLC

We shall now present a simple algorithm for constructing a parity check matrix for a magic square LDLC. If we look at the bipartite graph, each variable node and each check node has dğ‘‘d edges connected to it, one with every possible weight h1,h2,â€¦â€‹hdsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}. All the edges that have the same weight hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} form a permutation from the variable nodes to the check nodes (or vice versa). The proposed algorithm generates dğ‘‘d random permutations and then searches sequentially and cyclically for 2-loops (two parallel edges from a variable node to a check node) and 4-loops (two variable nodes that both are connected to a pair of check nodes). When such a loop is found, a pair is swapped in one of the permutations such that the loop is removed. A detailed pseudo-code for this algorithm is given in Appendix G.

VI Decoder Implementation

Each PDF should be approximated with a discrete vector with resolution Î”Î”\Delta and finite range. According to the Gaussian Q-function, choosing a range of, say, 6â€‹Ïƒ6ğœ6\sigma to both sides of the noisy channel observation will ensure that the error probability due to PDF truncation will be â‰ˆ10âˆ’9absentsuperscript109\approx 10^{-9}. Near capacity, Ïƒ2â‰ˆ12â€‹Ï€â€‹esuperscriptğœ212ğœ‹ğ‘’\sigma^{2}\approx\frac{1}{2\pi e}, so 12â€‹Ïƒâ‰ˆ312ğœ312\sigma\approx 3. Simulation showed that resolution errors became negligible for Î”=1/64Î”164\Delta=1/64. Each PDF was then stored in a L=256ğ¿256L=256 elements vector, corresponding to a range of size 444.

At the check node, the PDF fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x) that arrives from variable node jğ‘—j is first expanded by hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} (the appropriate coefficient of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}) to get fjâ€‹(x/hj)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘—f_{j}(x/h_{j}). In a discrete implementation with resolution Î”Î”\Delta the PDF is a vector of values fjâ€‹(kâ€‹Î”)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘˜Î”f_{j}(k\Delta), kâˆˆâ„¤ğ‘˜â„¤k\in\mathbb{Z}. As described in Section V, we shall usually use hjâ‰¤1subscriptâ„ğ‘—1h_{j}\leq 1 so the expanded PDF will be shorter than the original PDF. If the expand factor 1/|hj|1subscriptâ„ğ‘—1/|h_{j}| was an integer, we could simply decimate fjâ€‹(kâ€‹Î”)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘˜Î”f_{j}(k\Delta) by 1/|hj|1subscriptâ„ğ‘—1/|h_{j}|. However, in general it is not an integer so we should use some kind of interpolation. The PDF fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x) is certainly not band limited, and as the iterations go on it approaches an impulse, so simple interpolation methods (e.g. linear) are not suitable. Suppose that we need to calculate fjâ€‹((k+Ïµ)â€‹Î”)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘˜italic-ÏµÎ”f_{j}((k+\epsilon)\Delta), where âˆ’0.5â‰¤Ïµâ‰¤0.50.5italic-Ïµ0.5-0.5\leq\epsilon\leq 0.5. A simple interpolation method which showed to be effective is to average fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x) around the desired point, where the averaging window length lwsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘¤l_{w} is chosen to ensure that every sample of fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f_{j}(x) is used in the interpolation of at least one output point. This ensures that an impulse can not be missed. The interpolation result is then 12â€‹lw+1â€‹âˆ‘i=âˆ’lwlwfjâ€‹((kâˆ’i)â€‹Î”)12subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¤1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘–Î”\frac{1}{2l_{w}+1}\sum_{i=-l_{w}}^{l_{w}}f_{j}((k-i)\Delta), where lw=âŒŠâŒˆ1/|hj|âŒ‰2âŒ‹subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¤1subscriptâ„ğ‘—2l_{w}=\left\lfloor\frac{\left\lceil 1/|h_{j}|\right\rceil}{2}\right\rfloor.

The most computationally extensive step at the check nodes is the calculation the convolution of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 expanded PDFâ€™s. An efficient method is to calculate the fast Fourier transforms (FFTs) of all the PDFâ€™s, multiply the results and then perform inverse FFT (IFFT). The resolution of the FFT should be larger than the expected convolution length, which is roughly Loâ€‹uâ€‹tâ‰ˆLâ‹…âˆ‘i=1dhisubscriptğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡â‹…ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–L_{out}\approx L\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{d}h_{i}, where Lğ¿L denotes the original PDF length. Appendix H shows a way to use FFTs of size 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta, where Î”Î”\Delta is the resolution of the PDF. Usually 1/Î”<<Loâ€‹uâ€‹tmuch-less-than1Î”subscriptğ¿ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡1/\Delta<<L_{out} so FFT complexity is significantly reduced. Practical values are L=256ğ¿256L=256 and Î”=1/64Î”164\Delta=1/64, which give an improvement factor of at least 444 in complexity.

Each variable node receives dğ‘‘d check node messages. The output variable node message is calculated by generating the product of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 input messages and the channel Gaussian. As the iterations go on, the messages get narrow and may become impulses, with only a single nonzero sample. Quantization effects may cause impulses in two messages to be shifted by one sample. This will result in a zero output (instead of an impulse). Therefore, it was found useful to widen each check node message Qâ€‹(k)ğ‘„ğ‘˜Q(k) prior to multiplication, such that Qwâ€‹(k)=âˆ‘i=âˆ’11Qâ€‹(k+i)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘¤ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–11ğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘–Q_{w}(k)=\sum_{i=-1}^{1}Q(k+i), i.e. the message is added to its right shifted and left shifted (by one sample) versions.

VII Computational Complexity and Storage Requirements

Most of the computational effort is invested in the dğ‘‘d FFTâ€™s and dğ‘‘d IFFTâ€™s (of length 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta) that each check node performs each iteration. The total number of multiplications for tğ‘¡t iterations is oâ€‹(nâ‹…dâ‹…tâ‹…1Î”â‹…log2â¡(1Î”))ğ‘œâ‹…ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡1Î”subscript21Î”o\left(n\cdot d\cdot t\cdot\frac{1}{\Delta}\cdot\log_{2}(\frac{1}{\Delta})\right). As in binary LDPC codes, the computational complexity has the attractive property of being linear with block length. However, the constant that precedes the linear term is significantly higher, mainly due to the FFT operations.

The memory requirements are governed by the storage of the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd check node and variable node messages, with total memory of oâ€‹(nâ‹…dâ‹…L)ğ‘œâ‹…ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ¿o(n\cdot d\cdot L). Compared to binary LDPC, the factor of Lğ¿L significantly increases the required memory. For example, for n=10,000ğ‘›10000n=10,000, d=7ğ‘‘7d=7 and L=256ğ¿256L=256, the number of storage elements is of the order of 107superscript10710^{7}.

VIII Encoding and Shaping

VIII-A Encoding

The LDLC encoder has to calculate xÂ¯=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}, where bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} is an integer message vector. Note that unlike ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}, ğ‘®=ğ‘¯âˆ’1ğ‘®superscriptğ‘¯1\boldsymbol{G}=\boldsymbol{H}^{-1} is not sparse, in general, so the calculation requires computational complexity and storage of oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›2o(n^{2}). This is not a desirable property because the decoderâ€™s computational complexity is only oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n). A possible solution is to use the Jacobi method [22] to solve ğ‘¯â‹…xÂ¯=bÂ¯â‹…ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}=\underline{b}, which is a system of sparse linear equations. Using this method, a magic square LDLC encoder calculates several iterations of the form:

xÂ¯(t)=bÂ¯~âˆ’ğ‘¯~â‹…xÂ¯(tâˆ’1)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡Â¯~ğ‘â‹…~ğ‘¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\underline{x}^{(t)}=\underline{\tilde{b}}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}}\cdot\underline{x}^{(t-1)} (24)

with initialization xÂ¯(0)=0Â¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0Â¯0\underline{x}^{(0)}=\underline{0}. The matrix ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is defined in Lemma 6 of Section IV-C. The vector bÂ¯~Â¯~ğ‘\underline{\tilde{b}} is a permuted and scaled version of the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, such that the iğ‘–iâ€™th element of bÂ¯~Â¯~ğ‘\underline{\tilde{b}} equals the element of bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} for which the appropriate row of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} has its largest magnitude value at the iğ‘–iâ€™th location. This element is further divided by this largest magnitude element.

A necessary and sufficient condition for convergence to xÂ¯=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b} is that all the eigenvalues of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} have magnitude less than 111 [22]. However, it was shown that this is also a necessary condition for convergence of the LDLC iterative decoder (see Sections IV-C, V-B), so it is guaranteed to be fulfilled for a properly designed magic square LDLC. Since ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is sparse, this is an oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) algorithm, both in complexity and storage.

VIII-B Shaping

For practical use with the power constrained AWGN channel, the encoding operation must be accompanied by shaping, in order to prevent the transmitted codewordâ€™s power from being too large. Therefore, instead of mapping the information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} to the lattice point xÂ¯=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}, it should be mapped to some other lattice point xÂ¯â€²=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥â€²â‹…ğ‘®superscriptÂ¯ğ‘â€²\underline{x}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}^{\prime}, such that the lattice points that are used as codewords belong to a shaping region (e.g. an nğ‘›n-dimensional sphere). The shaping operation is the mapping of the integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} to the integer vector bÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘â€²\underline{b}^{\prime}.

As explained in Section II-A, this work concentrates on the lattice design and the lattice decoding algorithm, and not on the shaping region or shaping algorithms. Therefore, this section will only highlight some basic shaping principles and ideas.

A natural shaping scheme for lattice codes is nested lattice coding [12]. In this scheme, shaping is done by quantizing the lattice point ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b} onto a coarse lattice ğ‘®â€²superscriptğ‘®â€²\boldsymbol{G}^{\prime}, where the transmitted codeword is the quantization error, which is uniformly distributed along the Voronoi cell of the coarse lattice. If the second moment of this Voronoi cell is close to that of an nğ‘›n-dimensional sphere, the scheme will attain close-to-optimal shaping gain. Specifically, assume that the information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} assumes integer values in the range 0,1,â€¦â€‹Mâˆ’101â€¦ğ‘€10,1,...M-1 for some constant integer Mğ‘€M. Then, we can choose the coarse lattice to be ğ‘®â€²=Mâ€‹ğ‘®superscriptğ‘®bold-â€²ğ‘€ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G^{\prime}}=M\boldsymbol{G}. The volume of the Voronoi cell for this lattice is Mnsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M^{n}, since we assume dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘®)=1ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘®1det(\boldsymbol{G})=1 (see Section II-A). If the shape of the Voronoi cell resembles an nğ‘›n-dimensional sphere (as expected from a capacity approaching lattice code), it will attain optimal shaping gain (compared to uncoded transmission of the original integer sequence bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}).

The shaping operation will find the coarse lattice point Mâ€‹ğ‘®â€‹kÂ¯ğ‘€ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘˜M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k}, kÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nÂ¯ğ‘˜superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›\underline{k}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}, which is closest to the fine lattice point xÂ¯=ğ‘®â‹…bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{b}. The transmitted codeword will be:

xÂ¯â€²=xÂ¯âˆ’Mâ€‹ğ‘®â€‹kÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹(bÂ¯âˆ’Mâ€‹kÂ¯)=ğ‘®â€‹bâ€²Â¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥â€²Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘€ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘®Â¯superscriptğ‘â€²\displaystyle\underline{x}^{\prime}=\underline{x}-M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k}=\boldsymbol{G}(\underline{b}-M\underline{k})=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b^{\prime}}

where bÂ¯â€²=Î”bÂ¯âˆ’Mâ€‹kÂ¯superscriptÎ”superscriptÂ¯ğ‘â€²Â¯ğ‘ğ‘€Â¯ğ‘˜\underline{b}^{\prime}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{b}-M\underline{k} (note that the â€œinverse shapingâ€ at the decoder, i.e. transforming from bÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘â€²\underline{b}^{\prime} to bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}, is a simple modulo calculation: bÂ¯=bÂ¯â€²modMÂ¯ğ‘modulosuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘â€²ğ‘€\underline{b}=\underline{b}^{\prime}\mod M). Finding the closest coarse lattice point Mâ€‹ğ‘®â€‹kÂ¯ğ‘€ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘˜M\boldsymbol{G}\underline{k} to xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is equivalent to finding the closest fine lattice point ğ‘®â‹…kÂ¯â‹…ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{G}\cdot\underline{k} to the vector xÂ¯/MÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘€\underline{x}/M. This is exactly the operation of the iterative LDLC decoder, so we could expect that is could be used for shaping. However, simulations show that the iterative decoding finds a vector kÂ¯Â¯ğ‘˜\underline{k} with poor shaping gain. The reason is that for shaping, the effective noise is much stronger than for decoding, and the iterative decoder fails to find the nearest lattice point if the noise is too large (see Section IV-D).

Therefore, an alternative algorithm has to be used for finding the nearest coarse lattice point. The complexity of finding the nearest lattice point grows exponentially with the lattice dimension nğ‘›n and is not feasible for large dimensions [23]. However, unlike decoding, for shaping applications it is not critical to find the exact nearest lattice point, and approximate algorithms may be considered (see [15]). A possible method [24] is to perform QR decomposition on ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} in order to transform to a lattice with upper triangular generator matrix, and then use sequential decoding algorithms (such as the Fano algorithm) to search the resulting tree. The main disadvantage of this approach is computational complexity and storage of at least oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›2o(n^{2}). Finding an efficient shaping scheme for LDLC is certainly a topic for further research.

IX Simulation Results

Magic square LDLC with the first generating sequence of Section V-A (i.e. {1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55}12.3113.1715.1117.33111.71113.11117.55\{1/2.31,1/3.17,1/5.11,1/7.33,1/11.71,1/13.11,1/17.55\}) were simulated for the AWGN channel at various block lengths. The degree was d=5ğ‘‘5d=5 for n=100ğ‘›100n=100 and d=7ğ‘‘7d=7 for all other nğ‘›n. For n=100ğ‘›100n=100 the matrix ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} was further normalized to get dâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ‘¯)n=1ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘¯1\sqrt[n]{det(\boldsymbol{H})}=1. For all other nğ‘›n, normalizing the generating sequence such that the largest element has magnitude 111 also gave the desired determinant normalization (see Section V-B). The ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} matrices were generated using the algorithm of Section V-C. PDF resolution was set to Î”=1/256Î”1256\Delta=1/256 with a total range of 444, i.e. each PDF was represented by a vector of L=1024ğ¿1024L=1024 elements. High resolution was used since our main target is to prove the LDLC concept and eliminate degradation due to implementation considerations. For this reason, the decoder was used with 200 iterations (though most of the time, a much smaller number was sufficient).

In all simulations the all-zero codeword was used. Approaching channel capacity is equivalent to Ïƒ2â†’12â€‹Ï€â€‹eâ†’superscriptğœ212ğœ‹ğ‘’\sigma^{2}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2\pi e} (see Section II-A), so performance is measured in symbol error rate (SER), vs. the distance of the noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} from capacity (in dB). The results are shown in Figure 4. At SER of 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}, for n=100000ğ‘›100000n=100000, 100001000010000, 100010001000, 100100100 we can work as close as 0.60.60.6dB, 0.80.80.8dB, 1.51.51.5dB and 3.73.73.7dB from capacity, respectively.

Similar results were obtained for d=7ğ‘‘7d=7 with the second type of generating sequence of Section V-A, i.e. {1,17,17,17,17,17,17}1171717171717\{1,\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{7}}\}. Results were slightly worse than for the first generating sequence (by less than 0.1 dB). Increasing dğ‘‘d did not give any visible improvement.

X Conclusion

Low density lattice codes (LDLC) were introduced. LDLC are novel lattice codes that can approach capacity and be decoded efficiently. Good error performance within âˆ¼0.5similar-toabsent0.5\sim 0.5dB from capacity at block length of 100,000 symbols was demonstrated. Convergence analysis was presented for the iterative decoder, which is not complete, but yields necessary conditions on ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} and significant insight to the convergence process. Code parameters were chosen from intuitive arguments, so it is reasonable to assume that when the code structure will be more understood, better parameters could be found, and channel capacity could be approached even closer.

Multi-input, multi-output (MIMO) communication systems have become popular in recent years. Lattice codes have been proposed in this context as space-time codes (LAST) [25]. The concatenation of the lattice encoder and the MIMO channel generates a lattice. If LDLC are used as lattice codes and the MIMO configuration is small, the inverse generator matrix of this concatenated lattice can be assumed to be sparse. Therefore, the MIMO channel and the LDLC can be jointly decoded using an LDLC-like decoder. However, even if a magic square LDLC is used as the lattice code, the concatenated lattice is not guaranteed to be equivalent to a magic square LDLC, and the necessary conditions for convergence are not guaranteed to be fulfilled. Therefore, the usage of LDLC for MIMO systems is a topic for further research.

Appendix A Exact PDF Calculations

Given the nğ‘›n-dimensional noisy observation yÂ¯=xÂ¯+wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{y}=\underline{x}+\underline{w} of the transmitted codeword xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, we would like to calculate the probability density function (PDF) fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y}). We shall start by calculating fxÂ¯|yÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯|yÂ¯)=fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)â€‹fyÂ¯|xÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯|xÂ¯)fyÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¦f_{\underline{x}|\underline{y}}(\underline{x}|\underline{y})=\frac{f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})f_{\underline{y}|\underline{x}}(\underline{y}|\underline{x})}{f_{\underline{y}}(\underline{y})}. Denote the shaping region by BğµB (ğ‘®ğ‘®\boldsymbol{G} will be used to denote both the lattice and its generator matrix). fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) is a sum of |ğ‘®âˆ©B|ğ‘®ğµ|\boldsymbol{G}\cap B| nğ‘›n-dimensional Dirac delta functions, since xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} has nonzero probability only for the lattice points that lie inside the shaping region. Assuming further that all codewords are used with equal probability, all these delta functions have equal weight of 1|ğ‘®âˆ©B|1ğ‘®ğµ\frac{1}{|\boldsymbol{G}\cap B|}. The expression for fyÂ¯|xÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯|xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{y}|\underline{x}}(\underline{y}|\underline{x}) is simply the PDF of the i.i.d Gaussian noise vector. We therefore get:

fxÂ¯|yÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯|yÂ¯)=fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)â€‹fyÂ¯|xÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯|xÂ¯)fyÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯)=subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f_{\underline{x}|\underline{y}}(\underline{x}|\underline{y})=\frac{f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})f_{\underline{y}|\underline{x}}(\underline{y}|\underline{x})}{f_{\underline{y}}(\underline{y})}= (25)
1|ğ‘®âˆ©B|â€‹âˆ‘lÂ¯âˆˆğ‘®âˆ©BÎ´â€‹(xÂ¯âˆ’lÂ¯)â‹…(2â€‹Ï€â€‹Ïƒ2)âˆ’n/2â€‹eâˆ’âˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’xi)2/2â€‹Ïƒ2fyÂ¯â€‹(yÂ¯)=1ğ‘®ğµsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘®ğµâ‹…ğ›¿Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘™superscript2ğœ‹superscriptğœ2ğ‘›2superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–22superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle\frac{\frac{1}{|\boldsymbol{G}\cap B|}\sum_{\underline{l}\in\boldsymbol{G}\cap B}\delta(\underline{x}-\underline{l})\cdot(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-n/2}e^{-\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_{i}-x_{i})^{2}/2\sigma^{2}}}{f_{\underline{y}}(\underline{y})}=
=Câ‹…âˆ‘lÂ¯âˆˆğ‘®âˆ©BÎ´â€‹(xÂ¯âˆ’lÂ¯)â‹…eâˆ’d2â€‹(lÂ¯,yÂ¯)/2â€‹Ïƒ2absentâ‹…ğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘®ğµâ‹…ğ›¿Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘™superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘‘2Â¯ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘¦2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle=C\cdot\sum_{\underline{l}\in\boldsymbol{G}\cap B}\delta(\underline{x}-\underline{l})\cdot e^{-d^{2}(\underline{l},\underline{y})/2\sigma^{2}}

Where Cğ¶C is not a function of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} and d2â€‹(lÂ¯,yÂ¯)superscriptğ‘‘2Â¯ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘¦d^{2}(\underline{l},\underline{y}) is the squared Euclidean distance between the vectors lÂ¯Â¯ğ‘™\underline{l} and yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y} in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}. It can be seen that the conditional PDF of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} has a delta function for each lattice point, located at this lattice point with weight that is proportional to the exponent of the negated squared Euclidean distance of this lattice point from the noisy observation. The ML point corresponds to the delta function with largest weight.

As the next step, instead of calculating the nğ‘›n-dimensional PDF of the whole vector xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}, we shall calculate the nğ‘›n one-dimensional PDFâ€™s for each of the components xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} of the vector xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} (conditioned on the whole observation vector yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}):

fxk|yÂ¯â€‹(xk|yÂ¯)=subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f_{x_{k}|\underline{y}}(x_{k}|\underline{y})= (26)
âˆ«âˆ«xi,iâ‰ kâ‹¯â€‹âˆ«fxÂ¯|yÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯|yÂ¯)â€‹ğ‘‘x1â€‹ğ‘‘x2â€‹â‹¯â€‹ğ‘‘xkâˆ’1â€‹ğ‘‘xk+1â€‹â‹¯â€‹ğ‘‘xn=subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘˜â‹¯subscriptğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥1differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥2â‹¯differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1â‹¯differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›absent\displaystyle\int\int_{x_{i},i\neq k}\cdots\int f_{\underline{x}|\underline{y}}(\underline{x}|\underline{y})dx_{1}dx_{2}\cdots dx_{k-1}dx_{k+1}\cdots dx_{n}=
=Câ‹…âˆ‘lÂ¯âˆˆğ‘®âˆ©BÎ´â€‹(xkâˆ’lk)â‹…eâˆ’d2â€‹(lÂ¯,yÂ¯)/2â€‹Ïƒ2absentâ‹…ğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğ‘™ğ‘®ğµâ‹…ğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘™ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘‘2Â¯ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘¦2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle=C\cdot\sum_{\underline{l}\in\boldsymbol{G}\cap B}\delta(x_{k}-l_{k})\cdot e^{-d^{2}(\underline{l},\underline{y})/2\sigma^{2}}

This finishes the proof of (1). It can be seen that the conditional PDF of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} has a delta function for each lattice point, located at the projection of this lattice point on the coordinate xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, with weight that is proportional to the exponent of the negated squared Euclidean distance of this lattice point from the noisy observation. The ML point will therefore correspond to the delta function with largest weight in each coordinate. Note, however, that if several lattice points have the same projection on a specific coordinate, the weights of the corresponding delta functions will add and may exceed the weight of the ML point.

Appendix B Extending Gallagerâ€™s Technique to the Continuous Case

In [5], the derivation of the LDPC iterative decoder was simplified using the following technique: the codeword elements xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} were assumed i.i.d. and a condition was added to all the probability calculations, such that only valid codewords were actually considered. The question is then how to choose the marginal PDF of the codeword elements. In [5], binary codewords were considered, and the i.i.d distribution assumed the values â€™0â€™ and â€™1â€™ with equal probability. Since we extend the technique to the continuous case, we have to set the continuous marginal distribution fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}). It should be set such that fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}), assuming that xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is a lattice point, is the same as fâ€‹(xÂ¯|sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤n)ğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘ superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›f(\underline{x}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}), assuming that xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} are i.i.d with marginal PDF fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}), where sÂ¯=Î”ğ‘¯â‹…xÂ¯superscriptÎ”Â¯ğ‘ â‹…ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. This fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) equals a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions at all lattice points, where the weight at each lattice point equals the probability to use this point as a codeword.

Before proceeding, we need the following property of conditional probabilities. For any two continuous valued RVâ€™s uğ‘¢u, vğ‘£v we have:

fâ€‹(u|vâˆˆ{v1,v2,â€¦,vN})=âˆ‘k=1Nfu,vâ€‹(u,vk)âˆ‘k=1Nfvâ€‹(vk)ğ‘“conditionalğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘£subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜\displaystyle f(u|v\in\{v_{1},v_{2},...,v_{N}\})=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}f_{u,v}(u,v_{k})}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}f_{v}(v_{k})} (27)

(This property can be easily proved by following the lines of [21], pp. 159-160, and can also be extended to the infinite sum case).

Using (27), we now have:

fâ€‹(xÂ¯|sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤n)=âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nfxÂ¯,sÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯,sÂ¯=iÂ¯)âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nfsÂ¯â€‹(iÂ¯)=ğ‘“conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘ superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘ Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘ Â¯ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘ Â¯ğ‘–absent\displaystyle f(\underline{x}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n})=\frac{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f_{\underline{x},\underline{s}}(\underline{x},\underline{s}=\underline{i})}{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f_{\underline{s}}(\underline{i})}=
=Câ€‹âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nfâ€‹(xÂ¯)â€‹fâ€‹(sÂ¯=iÂ¯|xÂ¯)=Câ€²â€‹âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤nfâ€‹(xÂ¯)â€‹Î´â€‹(xÂ¯âˆ’ğ‘®â€‹iÂ¯)absentğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘“Â¯ğ‘ conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘¥superscriptğ¶â€²subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥ğ›¿Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘–\displaystyle=C\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f(\underline{x})f(\underline{s}=\underline{i}|\underline{x})=C^{\prime}\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}f(\underline{x})\delta(\underline{x}-\boldsymbol{G}\underline{i}) (28)

where C,Câ€²ğ¶superscriptğ¶â€²C,C^{\prime} are independent of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}.

The result is a weighted sum of Dirac delta functions at all lattice points, as desired. Now, the weight at each lattice point should equal the probability to use this point as a codeword. Therefore, fxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) should be chosen such that at each lattice point, the resulting vector distribution fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)=âˆk=1nfxkâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}f_{x_{k}}(x_{k}) will have a value that is proportional to the probability to use this lattice point. At xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} which is not a lattice point, the value of fxÂ¯â€‹(xÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¥f_{\underline{x}}(\underline{x}) is not important.

Appendix C Derivation of the Iterative Decoder

In this appendix we shall derive the LDLC iterative decoder for a code with dimension nğ‘›n, using the tree assumption and Gallagerâ€™s trick.

Referring to figure 2, assume that there are only 2 tiers. Using Gallagerâ€™s trick we assume that the xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}â€™s are i.i.d. We would like to calculate f(x1|(yÂ¯,sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤n)f(x_{1}|(\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}), where sÂ¯=Î”ğ‘¯â‹…xÂ¯superscriptÎ”Â¯ğ‘ â‹…ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{s}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}\cdot\underline{x}. Due to the tree assumption, we can do it in two steps:

1. calculate the conditional PDF of the tier 1 variables of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}, conditioned only on the check equations that relate the tier 1 and tier 2 variables.

2. calculate the conditional PDF of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} itself, conditioned only on the check equations that relate x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} and its first tier variables, but using the results of step 1 as the PDFâ€™s for the tier 1 variables. Hence, the results will be equivalent to conditioning on all the check equations.

There is a basic difference between the calculation in step 1 and step 2: the condition in step 2 involves all the check equations that are related to x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}, where in step 1 a single check equation is always omitted (the one that relates the relevant tier 1 element with x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} itself).

Assume now that there are many tiers, where each tier contains distinct elements of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} (i.e. each element appears only once in the resulting tree). We can then start at the farthest tier and start moving toward x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}. We do it by repeatedly calculating step 1. After reaching tier 1, we use step 2 to finally calculate the desired conditional PDF for x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}.

This approach suggests an iterative algorithm for the calculation of f(xk|(yÂ¯,sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤n)f(x_{k}|(\underline{y},\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}) for kğ‘˜k=1,2..n1,2..n. In this approach we assume that the resulting tier diagram for each xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} contains distinct elements for several tiers (larger or equal to the number of required iterations). We then repeat step 1 several times, where the results of the previous iteration are used as initial PDFâ€™s for the next iteration. Finally, we perform step 2 to calculate the final results.

Note that by conditioning only on part of the check equations in each iteration, we can not restrict the result to the shaping region. This is the reason that the decoder performs lattice decoding and not exact ML decoding, as described in Section III.

We shall now turn to derive the basic iteration of the algorithm. For simplicity, we shall start with the final step of the algorithm (denoted step 2 above). We would like to perform tğ‘¡t iterations, so assume that for each xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} there are tğ‘¡t tiers with a total of Ncsubscriptğ‘ğ‘N_{c} check equations. For every xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} we need to calculate fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤Nc,yÂ¯)=fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)âˆˆâ„¤ck,sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r2:tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹rt)âˆˆâ„¤Ncâˆ’ck,yÂ¯)ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘ superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘“formulae-sequenceconditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ :ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦f(x_{k}|\underline{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}},\underline{y})=f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}-c_{k}},\underline{y}), where cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} is the number of check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=Î”ğ‘¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)â‹…xÂ¯superscriptÎ”superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1â‹…superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\boldsymbol{H}^{(tier_{1})}\cdot\underline{x} denotes the value of the left hand side of these check equations when xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} is substituted (ğ‘¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1\boldsymbol{H}^{(tier_{1})} is a submatrix of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} that contains only the rows that relate to these check equations), and sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r2:tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹rt)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ :ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})} relates in the same manner to all the other check equations. For simplicity of notations, denote the event sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r2:tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹rt)âˆˆâ„¤Ncâˆ’cksuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ :ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}-c_{k}} by Ağ´A. As explained above, in all the calculations we assume that all the xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}â€™s are independent.

Using (27), we get:

fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)âˆˆâ„¤ck,A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},A,\underline{y})=
=âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤ckfâ€‹(xk,sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=iÂ¯|A,yÂ¯)âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤ckfâ€‹(sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=iÂ¯|A,yÂ¯)absentsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘“superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}}}f(x_{k},\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}=\underline{i}|A,\underline{y})}{\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}}}f(\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}=\underline{i}|A,\underline{y})} (29)

Evaluating the term inside the sum of the nominator, we get:

fâ€‹(xk,sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=iÂ¯|A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(x_{k},\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}=\underline{i}|A,\underline{y})=
=fâ€‹(xk|A,yÂ¯)â‹…fâ€‹(sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=iÂ¯|xk,A,yÂ¯)absentâ‹…ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘“superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle=f(x_{k}|A,\underline{y})\cdot f(\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}=\underline{i}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}) (30)

Evaluating the left term, we get:

fâ€‹(xk|A,yÂ¯)=fâ€‹(xk|yk)=fâ€‹(xk)â€‹fâ€‹(yk|xk)fâ€‹(yk)=ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle f(x_{k}|A,\underline{y})=f(x_{k}|y_{k})=\frac{f(x_{k})f(y_{k}|x_{k})}{f(y_{k})}=
=fâ€‹(xk)fâ€‹(yk)â‹…12â€‹Ï€â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2absentâ‹…ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜12ğœ‹superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2\displaystyle=\frac{f(x_{k})}{f(y_{k})}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}} (31)

where fâ€‹(xk|yÂ¯)=fâ€‹(xk|yk)ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜f(x_{k}|\underline{y})=f(x_{k}|y_{k}) due to the i.i.d assumption. Evaluating now the right term of (C), we get:

fâ€‹(sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=iÂ¯|xk,A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalÂ¯ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}=\underline{i}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})=
=âˆm=1ckfâ€‹(sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=im|xk,A,yÂ¯)absentsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle=\prod_{m=1}^{c_{k}}f(s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=i_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}) (32)

where sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1s_{m}^{(tier_{1})} denotes the mğ‘šmâ€™th component of sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})} and imsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘ši_{m} denotes the mğ‘šmâ€™th component of iÂ¯Â¯ğ‘–\underline{i}. Note that each element of sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})} is a linear combination of several elements of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}. Due to the tree assumption, two such linear combinations have no common elements, except for xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} itself, which appears in all linear combinations. However, xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is given, so the i.i.d assumption implies that all these linear combinations are independent, so (C) is justified. The condition Ağ´A (i.e. sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r2:tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹rt)âˆˆâ„¤Ncâˆ’cksuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ :ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\underline{s}^{(tier_{2}:tier_{t})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{N_{c}-c_{k}}) does not impact the independence due to the tree assumption.

Substituting (C), (C), (C) back in (C), we get:

fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)âˆˆâ„¤ck,A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},A,\underline{y})= (33)
=Câ‹…fâ€‹(xk)â‹…eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘iÂ¯âˆˆâ„¤ckâˆm=1ckfâ€‹(sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=im|xk,A,yÂ¯)=absentâ‹…â‹…ğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2subscriptÂ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle=C\cdot f(x_{k})\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\sum_{\underline{i}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}}}\prod_{m=1}^{c_{k}}f(s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=i_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})=
=Câ‹…fâ€‹(xk)â‹…eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘i1âˆˆâ„¤âˆ‘i2âˆˆâ„¤â‹¯absentâ‹…â‹…ğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2subscriptsubscriptğ‘–1â„¤subscriptsubscriptğ‘–2â„¤â‹¯\displaystyle=C\cdot f(x_{k})\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\sum_{i_{1}\in\mathbb{Z}}\sum_{i_{2}\in\mathbb{Z}}\cdots
