=Câ‹…fâ€‹(xk)â‹…eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆm=1ckâˆ‘imâˆˆâ„¤fâ€‹(sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=im|xk,A,yÂ¯)absentâ‹…â‹…ğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šâ„¤ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle=C\cdot f(x_{k})\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{m=1}^{c_{k}}\sum_{i_{m}\in\mathbb{Z}}f(s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=i_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})

where Cğ¶C is independent of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}.

We shall now examine the term inside the sum: fâ€‹(sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=im|xk,A,yÂ¯)ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦f(s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=i_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}). Denote the linear combination that sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1s_{m}^{(tier_{1})} represents by:

sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=hm,1â€‹xk+âˆ‘l=2rmhm,lâ€‹xjlsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptâ„ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘™\displaystyle s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=h_{m,1}x_{k}+\sum_{l=2}^{r_{m}}h_{m,l}x_{j_{l}} (34)

where {hm,l}subscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘™\{h_{m,l}\}, l=1,2â€‹â€¦â€‹rmğ‘™12â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šl=1,2...r_{m} is the set of nonzero coefficients of the appropriate parity check equation, and jlsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘™{j_{l}} is the set of indices of the appropriate xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} elements (note that the set jlsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘™{j_{l}} depends on mğ‘šm but we omit the â€œmğ‘šmâ€ index for clarity of notations). Without loss of generality, hm,1subscriptâ„ğ‘š1h_{m,1} is assumed to be the coefficient of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. Define zm=Î”âˆ‘l=2rmhm,lâ€‹xjlsuperscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™2subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘™z_{m}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{l=2}^{r_{m}}h_{m,l}x_{j_{l}}, such that sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=hm,1â€‹xk+zmsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptâ„ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šs_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=h_{m,1}x_{k}+z_{m}. We then have:

fâ€‹(sm(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)=im|xk,A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(s_{m}^{(tier_{1})}=i_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})= (35)
=fzm|xk,A,yÂ¯â€‹(zm=imâˆ’hm,1â€‹xk|xk,A,yÂ¯)absentsubscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šconditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle=f_{z_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}}(z_{m}=i_{m}-h_{m,1}x_{k}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})

Now, since we assume that the elements of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} are independent, the PDF of the linear combination zmsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šz_{m} equals the convolution of the PDFâ€™s of its components:

fzm|xk,A,yÂ¯â€‹(zm|xk,A,yÂ¯)=subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f_{z_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}}(z_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y})=
=1|hm,2|fxj2|A,yÂ¯(zmhm,2|A,yÂ¯)âŠ›\displaystyle=\frac{1}{|h_{m,2}|}f_{x_{j_{2}}|A,\underline{y}}\left(\frac{z_{m}}{h_{m,2}}|A,\underline{y}\right)\circledast
âŠ›1|hm,3|fxj3|A,yÂ¯(zmhm,3|A,yÂ¯)âŠ›\displaystyle\circledast\frac{1}{|h_{m,3}|}f_{x_{j_{3}}|A,\underline{y}}\left(\frac{z_{m}}{h_{m,3}}|A,\underline{y}\right)\circledast
â‹¯âŠ›1|hm,rm|â€‹fxjrm|A,yÂ¯â€‹(zmhm,rm|A,yÂ¯)âŠ›â‹¯1subscriptâ„ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ´Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle\cdots\circledast\frac{1}{|h_{m,r_{m}}|}f_{x_{j_{r_{m}}}|A,\underline{y}}\left(\frac{z_{m}}{h_{m,r_{m}}}|A,\underline{y}\right) (36)

Note that the functions fxji|yÂ¯â€‹(xji|A,yÂ¯)subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘¦conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦f_{x_{j_{i}}|\underline{y}}\left(x_{j_{i}}|A,\underline{y}\right) are simply the output PDFâ€™s of the previous iteration.

Define now

pmâ€‹(xk)=Î”fzm|xk,A,yÂ¯â€‹(zm=âˆ’hm,1â€‹xk|xk,A,yÂ¯)superscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘§ğ‘šconditionalsubscriptâ„ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle p_{m}(x_{k})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}f_{z_{m}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}}(z_{m}=-h_{m,1}x_{k}|x_{k},A,\underline{y}) (37)

Substituting (35), (37) in (33), we finally get:

fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)âˆˆâ„¤ck,A,yÂ¯)=ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦absent\displaystyle f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},A,\underline{y})= (38)
=Câ‹…fâ€‹(xk)â‹…eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆm=1ckâˆ‘imâˆˆâ„¤pmâ€‹(xkâˆ’imhm,1)absentâ‹…â‹…ğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘š1\displaystyle=C\cdot f(x_{k})\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{m=1}^{c_{k}}\sum_{i_{m}\in\mathbb{Z}}p_{m}(x_{k}-\frac{i_{m}}{h_{m,1}})

This result can be summarized as follows. For each of the cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, the PDFâ€™s (previous iteration results) of the active equation elements, except for xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} itself, are expanded and convolved, according to (C). The convolution result is scaled by (âˆ’hm,1)subscriptâ„ğ‘š1(-h_{m,1}), the negated coefficient of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} in this check equation, according to (37), to yield pmâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜p_{m}(x_{k}). Then, a periodic function with period 1/|hm,1|1subscriptâ„ğ‘š11/|h_{m,1}| is generated by adding an infinite number of shifted versions of the scaled convolution result, according to the sum term in (38). After repeating this process for all the cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, we get cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} periodic functions, with possibly different periods. We then multiply all these functions. The multiplication result is further multiplied by the channel Gaussian PDF term eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}} and finally by fâ€‹(xk)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f(x_{k}), the marginal PDF of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} under the i.i.d assumption. As discussed in Section III, we assume that fâ€‹(xk)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f(x_{k}) is a uniform distribution with large enough range. This means that fâ€‹(xk)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f(x_{k}) is constant over the valid range of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, and can therefore be omitted from (38) and absorbed in the constant Cğ¶C.

As noted above, this result is for the final step (equivalent to step 2 above), where we determine the PDF of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} according to the PDFâ€™s of all its tier 1 elements. However, the repeated iteration step is equivalent to step 1 above. In this step ,we assume that xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is a tier 1 element of another element, say xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l}, and derive the PDF of xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} that should be used as input to step 2 of xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l} (see figure 2). It can be seen that the only difference between step 2 and step 1 is that in step 2 all the check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} are used, where in step 1 the check equation that involves both xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} and xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l} is ignored (there must be such an equation since xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is one of the tier 1 elements of xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l}). Therefore, the step1 iteration is identical to (38), except that the product does not contain the term that corresponds to the check equation that combines both xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} and xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l}. Denote

fkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)=Î”fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1â€‹eâ€‹xâ€‹câ€‹eâ€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹l)âˆˆâ„¤ckâˆ’1,A,yÂ¯)superscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘™superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\displaystyle f_{kl}(x_{k})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1}\ except\ l)}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}-1},A,\underline{y}) (39)

We then get:

fkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)=Câ‹…eâˆ’(ykâˆ’xk)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆm=1mâ‰ mlckâˆ‘imâˆˆâ„¤pmâ€‹(xkâˆ’imhm,1)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹…ğ¶superscriptğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptâ„ğ‘š1\displaystyle f_{kl}(x_{k})=C\cdot e^{-\frac{(y_{k}-x_{k})^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\prod_{\begin{subarray}{c}m=1\\ m\neq m_{l}\end{subarray}}^{c_{k}}\sum_{i_{m}\in\mathbb{Z}}p_{m}(x_{k}-\frac{i_{m}}{h_{m,1}}) (40)

where mlsubscriptğ‘šğ‘™m_{l} is the index of the check equation that combines both xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} and xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l}. In principle, a different fkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{kl}(x_{k}) should be calculated for each xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l} for which xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is a tier 1 element. However, the calculation is the same for all xlsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™x_{l} that share the same check equation. Therefore, we should calculate fkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{kl}(x_{k}) once for each check equation that involves xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. lğ‘™l can be regarded as the index of the check equation within the set of check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}.

We can now formulate the iterative decoder. The decoder state variables are PDFâ€™s of the form fkâ€‹l(t)â€‹(xk)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f^{(t)}_{kl}(x_{k}), where k=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘˜12â€¦ğ‘›k=1,2,...n. For each kğ‘˜k, lğ‘™l assumes the values 1,2,â€¦â€‹ck12â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1,2,...c_{k}, where cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} is the number of check equations that involve xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}. tğ‘¡t denotes the iteration index. For a regular LDLC with degree dğ‘‘d there will be nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd PDFâ€™s. The PDFâ€™s are initialized by assuming that xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} is a leaf of the tier diagram. Such a leaf has no tier 1 elements, so fkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)=fâ€‹(xk)â‹…fâ€‹(yk|xk)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹…ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f_{kl}(x_{k})=f(x_{k})\cdot f(y_{k}|x_{k}). As explained above for equation (38), we shall omit the term fâ€‹(xk)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f(x_{k}), resulting in initialization with the channel noise Gaussian around the noisy observation yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k}. Then, the PDFâ€™s are updated in each iteration according to (40). The variable node messages should be further normalized in order to get actual PDFâ€™s, such that âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆfkâ€‹lâ€‹(xk)â€‹ğ‘‘xk=1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜differential-dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f_{kl}(x_{k})dx_{k}=1 (this will compensate for the constant Cğ¶C). The final PDFâ€™s for xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k}, k=1,2,â€¦â€‹nğ‘˜12â€¦ğ‘›k=1,2,...n are then calculated according to (38).

Finally, we have to estimate the integer valued information vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}. This can be done by first estimating the codeword vector xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} from the peaks of the PDFâ€™s: xk^=aâ€‹râ€‹gâ€‹maxxkâ¡fâ€‹(xk|sÂ¯(tâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹r1)âˆˆâ„¤ck,A,yÂ¯)^subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘”subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘“conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ´Â¯ğ‘¦\hat{x_{k}}=arg\max_{x_{k}}f(x_{k}|\underline{s}^{(tier_{1})}\in\mathbb{Z}^{c_{k}},A,\underline{y}). Finally, we can estimate bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} as bÂ¯^=âŒŠğ‘¯xÂ¯^âŒ‰\underline{\hat{b}}=\left\lfloor\boldsymbol{H}\underline{\hat{x}}\right\rceil.

We have finished developing the iterative algorithm. It can be easily seen that the message passing formulation of Section III-A actually implements this algorithm.

Appendix D Asymptotic Behavior of the Variances Recursion

D-A Proof of Lemma 3 and Lemma 4

We shall now derive the basic iterative equations that relate the variances at iteration t+1ğ‘¡1t+1 to the variances at iteration tğ‘¡t for a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n, degree dğ‘‘d and generating sequence h1â‰¥h2â‰¥â€¦â‰¥hd>0subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘0h_{1}\geq h_{2}\geq...\geq h_{d}>0.

Each iteration, every check node generates dğ‘‘d output messages, one for each variable node that is connected to it, where the weights of these dğ‘‘d connections are Â±h1,Â±h2,â€¦,Â±hdplus-or-minussubscriptâ„1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„2â€¦plus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘‘\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the check node convolves dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 expanded variable node PDF messages, and then stretches and periodically extends the result. For a specific check node, denote the variance of the variable node message that arrives along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by Vj(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—V^{(t)}_{j}, j=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘—12â€¦ğ‘‘j=1,2,...d. Denote the variance of the message that is sent back to a variable node along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by V~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}. From (1), (3), we get:

V~j(t)=1hj2â€‹âˆ‘i=1iâ‰ jdhi2â€‹Vi(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{1}{h_{j}^{2}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{i}^{2}V^{(t)}_{i} (41)

Then, each variable node generates dğ‘‘d messages, one for each check node that is connected to it, where the weights of these dğ‘‘d connections are Â±h1,Â±h2,â€¦,Â±hdplus-or-minussubscriptâ„1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„2â€¦plus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘‘\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the variable node generates the product of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 check node messages and the channel noise PDF. For a specific variable node, denote the variance of the message that is sent back to a check node along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by Vj(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘—V^{(t+1)}_{j} (this is the final variance of the iteration). From claim 2, we then get:

1Vj(t+1)=âˆ‘i=1iâ‰ jd1V~i(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–1superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{j}}=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{1}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}} (42)

From symmetry considerations, it can be seen that all messages that are sent along edges with the same absolute value of their weight will have the same variance, since the same variance update occurs for all these messages (both for check node messages and variable node messages). Therefore, the dğ‘‘d variance values V1(t),V2(t),â€¦,Vd(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘‘V^{(t)}_{1},V^{(t)}_{2},...,V^{(t)}_{d} are the same for all variable nodes, where Vl(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘™V^{(t)}_{l} is the variance of the message that is sent along an edge with weight Â±hlplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘™\pm h_{l}. This completes the proof of Lemma 3.

Using this symmetry, we can now derive the recursive update of the variance values V1(t),V2(t),â€¦,Vd(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘‘V^{(t)}_{1},V^{(t)}_{2},...,V^{(t)}_{d}. Substituting (41) in (42), we get:

1Vi(t+1)=1Ïƒ2+âˆ‘m=1mâ‰ idhm2âˆ‘j=1jâ‰ mdhj2â€‹Vj(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘š2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘šğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—\displaystyle\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}m=1\\ m\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{h_{m}^{2}}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq m\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{j}^{2}V^{(t)}_{j}} (43)

for i=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...d, which completes the proof of Lemma 4.

D-B Proof of Theorem 1

We would like to analyze the convergence of the nonlinear recursion (4) for the variances V1(t),V2(t),â€¦,Vd(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘‘V^{(t)}_{1},V^{(t)}_{2},...,V^{(t)}_{d}. This recursion is illustrated in (5) for the case d=3ğ‘‘3d=3. It is assumed that Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, where Î±=âˆ‘i=2dhi2h12ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptâ„12\alpha=\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}. Define another set of variables U1(t),U2(t),â€¦,Ud(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘‘U^{(t)}_{1},U^{(t)}_{2},...,U^{(t)}_{d}, which obey the following recursion. The recursion for the first variable is:

1U1(t+1)=1Ïƒ2+âˆ‘m=2dhm2h12â€‹U1(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡111superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘š2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘š2superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1\displaystyle\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{1}}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{m=2}^{d}\frac{h_{m}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}U^{(t)}_{1}} (44)

where for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d the recursion is:

1Ui(t+1)=h12âˆ‘j=2dhj2â€‹Uj(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘—\displaystyle\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{i}}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{\sum_{j=2}^{d}h_{j}^{2}U^{(t)}_{j}}

with initial conditions U1(0)=U2(0)=â€¦=Ud(0)=Ïƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆ01subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆ02â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆ0ğ‘‘superscriptğœ2U^{(0)}_{1}=U^{(0)}_{2}=...=U^{(0)}_{d}=\sigma^{2}.

It can be seen that (44) can be regarded as the approximation of (4) under the assumptions that Vi(t)<<V1(t)much-less-thansubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1V^{(t)}_{i}<<V^{(t)}_{1} and Vi(t)<<Ïƒ2much-less-thansubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğœ2V^{(t)}_{i}<<\sigma^{2} for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d.

For illustration, the new recursion for the case d=3ğ‘‘3d=3 is:

1U1(t+1)=h22h12â€‹U1(t)+h32h12â€‹U1(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡11superscriptsubscriptâ„22superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptâ„32superscriptsubscriptâ„12subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡11superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{1}}=\frac{h_{2}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}U^{(t)}_{1}}+\frac{h_{3}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}U^{(t)}_{1}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}} (45)
1U2(t+1)=h12h22â€‹U2(t)+h32â€‹U3(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡12superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡3\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{2}}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{2}^{2}U^{(t)}_{2}+h_{3}^{2}U^{(t)}_{3}}
1U3(t+1)=h12h22â€‹U2(t)+h32â€‹U3(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡13superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„22subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptâ„32subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡3\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{3}}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{2}^{2}U^{(t)}_{2}+h_{3}^{2}U^{(t)}_{3}}

It can be seen that in the new recursion, U1(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1U^{(t)}_{1} obeys a recursion that is independent of the other variables. From (44), this recursion can be written as 1U1(t+1)=1Ïƒ2+Î±U1(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡111superscriptğœ2ğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{1}}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\frac{\alpha}{U^{(t)}_{1}}, with initial condition U1(0)=Ïƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆ01superscriptğœ2U^{(0)}_{1}=\sigma^{2}. Since Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, this is a stable linear recursion for 1U1(t)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1\frac{1}{U^{(t)}_{1}}, which can be solved to get U1(t)=Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹11âˆ’Î±t+1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1superscriptğœ21ğ›¼11superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡1U^{(t)}_{1}=\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)\frac{1}{1-\alpha^{t+1}}.

For the other variables, it can be seen that all have the same right hand side in the recursion (44). Since all are initialized with the same value, it follows that U2(t)=U3(t)=â€¦=Ud(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡3â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘‘U^{(t)}_{2}=U^{(t)}_{3}=...=U^{(t)}_{d} for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0. Substituting back in (44), we get the recursion U2(t+1)=Î±â€‹U2(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡12ğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2U^{(t+1)}_{2}=\alpha U^{(t)}_{2}, with initial condition U2(0)=Ïƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆ02superscriptğœ2U^{(0)}_{2}=\sigma^{2}. Since Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, this is a stable linear recursion for U2(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2U^{(t)}_{2}, which can be solved to get U2(t)=Ïƒ2â€‹Î±tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡2superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡U^{(t)}_{2}=\sigma^{2}\alpha^{t}.

We found an analytic solution for the variables Ui(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–U^{(t)}_{i}. However, we are interested in the variances Vi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–V^{(t)}_{i}. The following claim relates the two sets of variables.

Claim 3

For every tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0, the first variables of the two sets are related by V1(t)â‰¥U1(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1}, where for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d we have Vi(t)â‰¤Ui(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–V^{(t)}_{i}\leq U^{(t)}_{i}.

Proof:

By induction: the initialization of the two sets of variables obviously satisfies the required relations. Assume now that the relations are satisfied for iteration tğ‘¡t, i.e. V1(t)â‰¥U1(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1} and for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d, Vi(t)â‰¤Ui(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–V^{(t)}_{i}\leq U^{(t)}_{i}. If we now compare the right hand side of the update recursion for 1V1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡11\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{1}} to that of 1U1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡11\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{1}} (i.e. (4) to (44)), then the right hand side for 1V1(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡11\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{1}} is smaller, because it has additional positive terms in the denominators, where the common terms in the denominators are larger according to the induction assumption. Therefore, V1(t+1)â‰¥U1(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡11subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡11V^{(t+1)}_{1}\geq U^{(t+1)}_{1}, as required. In the same manner, if we compare the right hand side of the update recursion for 1Vi(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}} to that of 1Ui(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1ğ‘–\frac{1}{U^{(t+1)}_{i}} for iâ‰¥2ğ‘–2i\geq 2, then the right hand side for 1Vi(t+1)1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}} is larger, because it has additional positive terms, where the common terms are also larger since their denominators are smaller due to the induction assumption. Therefore, Vi(t+1)â‰¤Ui(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1ğ‘–V^{(t+1)}_{i}\leq U^{(t+1)}_{i} for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d, as required. âˆ

Using claim 3 and the analytic results for Ui(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–U^{(t)}_{i}, we now have:

V1(t)â‰¥U1(t)=Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹11âˆ’Î±t+1â‰¥Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1superscriptğœ21ğ›¼11superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡1superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\displaystyle V^{(t)}_{1}\geq U^{(t)}_{1}=\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)\frac{1}{1-\alpha^{t+1}}\geq\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) (46)

where for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d we have:

Vi(t)â‰¤Ui(t)=Ïƒ2â€‹Î±tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\displaystyle V^{(t)}_{i}\leq U^{(t)}_{i}=\sigma^{2}\alpha^{t} (47)

We have shown that the first variance is lower bounded by a positive nonzero constant where the other variances are upper bounded by a term that decays exponentially to zero. Therefore, for large tğ‘¡t we have Vi(t)<<V1(t)much-less-thansubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1V^{(t)}_{i}<<V^{(t)}_{1} and Vi(t)<<Ïƒ2much-less-thansubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğœ2V^{(t)}_{i}<<\sigma^{2} for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d. It then follows that for large tğ‘¡t the variances approximately obey the recursion (44), which was built from the actual variance recursion (4) under these assumptions. Therefore, for i=2,3,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3,...d the variances are not only upper bounded by an exponentially decaying term, but actually approach such a term, where the first variance actually approaches the constant Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) in an exponential rate. This completes the proof of Theorem 1.

Note that the above analysis only applies if Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1. To illustrate the behavior for Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1, consider the simple case of h1=h2=â€¦=hdsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘h_{1}=h_{2}=...=h_{d}. From (4), (5) it can be seen that for this case, if Vi(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰0ğ‘–V^{(0)}_{i} is independent of iğ‘–i, then Vi(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–V^{(t)}_{i} is independent of iğ‘–i for every t>0ğ‘¡0t>0, since all the elements will follow the same recursive equations. Substituting this result in the first equation, we get the single variable recursion 1Vi(t+1)=1Vi(t)+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡1ğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–1superscriptğœ2\frac{1}{V^{(t+1)}_{i}}=\frac{1}{V^{(t)}_{i}}+\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}} with initialization Vi(0)=Ïƒ2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰0ğ‘–superscriptğœ2V^{(0)}_{i}=\sigma^{2}. This recursion is easily solved to get 1Vi(t)=t+1Ïƒ21subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¡1superscriptğœ2\frac{1}{V^{(t)}_{i}}=\frac{t+1}{\sigma^{2}} or Vi(t)=Ïƒ2t+1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğœ2ğ‘¡1V^{(t)}_{i}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{t+1}. It can be seen that all the variances converge to zero, but with slow convergence rate of oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘œ1ğ‘¡o(1/t).

Appendix E Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean Values Recursion

E-A Proof of Lemma 5 and Lemma 6 (Mean of Narrow Messages)

Assume a magic square LDLC with dimension nğ‘›n and degree dğ‘‘d. We shall now examine the effect of the calculations in the check nodes and variable nodes on the mean values and derive the resulting recursion. Every iteration, each check node generates dğ‘‘d output messages, one for each variable node that connects to it, where the weights of these dğ‘‘d connections are Â±h1,Â±h2,â€¦,Â±hdplus-or-minussubscriptâ„1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„2â€¦plus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘‘\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the check node convolves dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 expanded variable node PDF messages, and then stretches and periodically extends the result. We shall concentrate on the nâ€‹dğ‘›ğ‘‘nd consistent Gaussians that relate to the same integer vector bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} (one Gaussian in each message), and analyze them jointly. For convenience, we shall refer to the mean value of the relevant consistent Gaussian as the mean of the message.

Consider now a specific check node. Denote the mean value of the variable node message that arrives at iteration tğ‘¡t along the edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by mj(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘—m^{(t)}_{j}, j=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘—12â€¦ğ‘‘j=1,2,...d. Denote the mean value of the message that is sent back to a variable node along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by m~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘—\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}. From (1), (3) and claim 1, we get:

m~j(t)=1hjâ€‹(bkâˆ’âˆ‘i=1iâ‰ jdhiâ€‹mi(t))subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{1}{h_{j}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{i}m^{(t)}_{i}\right) (48)

where bksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜b_{k} is the appropriate element of bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that is related to this specific check equation, which is the only relevant index in the infinite sum of the periodic extension step (3). Note that the check node operation is equivalent to extracting the value of mjsubscriptğ‘šğ‘—m_{j} from the check equation âˆ‘i=1dhiâ€‹mi=bksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\sum_{i=1}^{d}h_{i}m_{i}=b_{k}, assuming all the other misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i} are known. Note also that the coefficients hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} should have a random sign. To keep notations simple, we assume that hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} already includes the random sign. Later, when several equations will be combined together, we should take it into account.

Then, each variable node generates dğ‘‘d messages, one for each check node that is connected to it, where the weights of these dğ‘‘d connections are Â±h1,Â±h2,â€¦,Â±hdplus-or-minussubscriptâ„1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„2â€¦plus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘‘\pm h_{1},\pm h_{2},...,\pm h_{d}. For each such output message, the variable node generates the product of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 check node messages and the channel noise PDF. For a specific variable node, denote the mean value of the message that arrives from a check node along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} by m~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘—\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}, and the appropriate variance by V~j(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}. The mean value of the message that is sent back to a check node along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} is mj(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1ğ‘—m^{(t+1)}_{j}, the final mean value of the iteration. From claim 2, we then get:

mj(t+1)=yk/Ïƒ2+âˆ‘i=1iâ‰ jdm~i(t)/V~i(t)1/Ïƒ2+âˆ‘i=1iâ‰ jd1/V~i(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{j}=\frac{y_{k}/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{i}/\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}}{1/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=1\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}1/\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}} (49)

where yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k} is the channel observation for the variable node and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the noise variance. Note that m~i(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦,dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...,d in (49) are the mean values of check node messages that arrive to the same variable node from different check nodes, where in (48) they define the mean values of check node messages that leave the same check node. However, it is beneficial to keep the notations simple, and we shall take special care when (49) and (48) are combined.

It can be seen that the convergence of the mean values is coupled to the convergence of the variances (unlike the recursion of the variances which was autonomous). However, as the iterations go on, this coupling disappears. To see that, recall from Theorem 1 that for each check node, the variance of the variable node message that comes along an edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} approaches a finite value, where the variance of all the other messages approaches zero exponentially. According to (41), the variance of the check node message is a weighted sum of the variances of the incoming variable node messages. Therefore, the variance of the check node message that goes along an edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} will approach zero, since the weighted sum involves only zero-approaching variances. All the other messages will have finite variance, since the weighted sum involves the non zero-approaching variance. To summarize, each variable node sends (and each check node receives) dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 â€œnarrowâ€ messages and a single â€œwideâ€ message. Each check node sends (and each variable node receives) dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 â€œwideâ€ messages and a single â€œnarrowâ€ message, where the narrow message is sent along the edge from which the wide message was received (the edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}).

We shall now concentrate on the case where the variable node generates a narrow message. Then, the sum in the nominator of (49) has a single term for which V~i(t)â†’0â†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–0\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{i}\rightarrow 0, which corresponds to i=1ğ‘–1i=1. The same is true for the sum in the denominator. Therefore, for large tğ‘¡t, all the other terms will become negligible and we get:

mj(t+1)â‰ˆm~1(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1ğ‘—subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡1\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{j}\approx\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{1} (50)

where m~1(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡1\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{1} is the mean of the message that comes from the edge with weight h1subscriptâ„1h_{1}, i.e. the narrow check node message. As discussed above, dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 of the dğ‘‘d variable node messages that leave the same variable node are narrow. From (50) it comes out that for large tğ‘¡t, all these dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow messages will have the same mean value. This completes the proof of Lemma 5.

Now, combining (48) and (50) (where the indices are arranged again, as discussed above), we get:

ml1(t+1)â‰ˆ1h1â€‹(bkâˆ’âˆ‘i=2dhiâ€‹mli(t))subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™11subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{l_{1}}\approx\frac{1}{h_{1}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}m^{(t)}_{l_{i}}\right) (51)

where lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}, i=1,2â€‹â€¦,dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2...,d are the variable nodes that take place in the check equation for which variable node l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1} appears with coefficient Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}. bksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜b_{k} is the element of bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} that is related to this check equation. ml1(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™1m^{(t+1)}_{l_{1}} denotes the mean value of the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow messages that leave variable node l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1} at iteration t+1ğ‘¡1t+1. mli(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–m^{(t)}_{l_{i}} is the mean value of the narrow messages that were generated at variable node lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i} at iteration tğ‘¡t. Only narrow messages are involved in (51), because the right hand side of (50) is the mean value of the narrow check node message that arrived to variable node l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1}, which results from the convolution of dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow variable node messages. Therefore, for large tğ‘¡t, the mean values of the narrow messages are decoupled from the mean values of the wide messages (and also from the variances), and they obey an autonomous recursion.

The mean values of the narrow messages at iteration tğ‘¡t can be arranged in an nğ‘›n-element column vector mÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡\underline{m}^{(t)} (one mean value for each variable node). We would like to show that the mean values converge to the coordinates of the lattice point xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. Therefore, it is useful to define the error vector eÂ¯(t)=Î”mÂ¯(t)âˆ’xÂ¯superscriptÎ”superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘šğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{e}^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{m}^{(t)}-\underline{x}. Since ğ‘¯â€‹xÂ¯=bÂ¯ğ‘¯Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}\underline{x}=\underline{b}, we can write (using the same notations as (51)):

xl1=1h1â€‹(bkâˆ’âˆ‘i=2dhiâ€‹xli)subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘™11subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–\displaystyle x_{l_{1}}=\frac{1}{h_{1}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}x_{l_{i}}\right) (52)

Subtracting (52) from (51), we get:

el1(t+1)â‰ˆâˆ’1h1â€‹âˆ‘i=2dhiâ€‹eli(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™11subscriptâ„1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–\displaystyle e^{(t+1)}_{l_{1}}\approx-\frac{1}{h_{1}}\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}e^{(t)}_{l_{i}} (53)

Or, in vector notation:

eÂ¯(t+1)â‰ˆâˆ’ğ‘¯~â‹…eÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1â‹…~ğ‘¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}\approx-\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)} (54)

where ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} is derived from ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} by permuting the rows such that the Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} elements will be placed on the diagonal, dividing each row by the appropriate diagonal element (h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} or âˆ’h1subscriptâ„1-h_{1}), and then nullifying the diagonal. Note that in order to simplify the notations, we embedded the sign of Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} in hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} and did not write it implicitly. However, the definition of ğ‘¯~~ğ‘¯\tilde{\boldsymbol{H}} solves this ambiguity. This completes the proof of Lemma 6.

E-B Proof of Lemma 7 (Mean of Wide Messages)

Recall that each check node receives dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow messages and a single wide message. The wide message comes along the edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}. Denote the appropriate lattice point by xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}, and assume that the Gaussians of the narrow variable node messages have already converged to impulses at the corresponding lattice point coordinates (Theorem 2). We can then substitute in (48) mi(t)=xisubscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–m^{(t)}_{i}=x_{i} for iâ‰¥2ğ‘–2i\geq 2. The mean value of the (wide) message that is returned along the edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} (jâ‰ 1ğ‘—1j\neq 1) is:

m~j(t)=1hjâ€‹(bkâˆ’âˆ‘i=2iâ‰ jdhiâ€‹xiâˆ’h1â€‹m1(t))=subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptâ„1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1absent\displaystyle\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{1}{h_{j}}\left(b_{k}-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}i=2\\ i\neq j\end{subarray}}^{d}h_{i}x_{i}-h_{1}m^{(t)}_{1}\right)= (55)
=1hjâ€‹(h1â€‹x1+hjâ€‹xjâˆ’h1â€‹m1(t))=xj+h1hjâ€‹(x1âˆ’m1(t))absent1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1\displaystyle=\frac{1}{h_{j}}\left(h_{1}x_{1}+h_{j}x_{j}-h_{1}m^{(t)}_{1}\right)=x_{j}+\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}\left(x_{1}-m^{(t)}_{1}\right)

As in the previous section, for convenience of notations we embed the sign of Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} in hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} itself. The sign ambiguity will be resolved later.

The meaning of (55) is that the returned mean value is the desired lattice coordinate plus an error term that is proportional to the error in the incoming wide message. From (41), assuming that the variance of the incoming wide message has already converged to its steady state value Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) and the variance of the incoming narrow messages has already converged to zero, the variance of this check node message will be:

V~j(t)=h12hj2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\displaystyle\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{j}=\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) (56)

where Î±=âˆ‘i=2dhi2h12ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–2superscriptsubscriptâ„12\alpha=\frac{\sum_{i=2}^{d}h_{i}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}. Now, each variable node receives dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 wide messages and a single narrow message. The mean values of the wide messages are according to (55) and the variances are according to (56). The single wide message that this variable node generates results from the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 input wide messages and it is sent along the edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}. From (49), the wide mean value generated at variable node kğ‘˜k will then be:

mk(t+1)=subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{k}= (57)
=yk/Ïƒ2+âˆ‘j=2d(xk+h1hjâ€‹(xpâ€‹(k,j)âˆ’mpâ€‹(k,j)(t)))â€‹hj2h12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)1/Ïƒ2+âˆ‘j=2dhj2h12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)absentsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptğœ21ğ›¼1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\displaystyle=\frac{y_{k}/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{j=2}^{d}\left(x_{k}+\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}(x_{p(k,j)}-m^{(t)}_{p(k,j)})\right)\frac{h_{j}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}}{1/\sigma^{2}+\sum_{j=2}^{d}\frac{h_{j}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}}

Note that the x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} and m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} terms of (55) were replaced by xpâ€‹(k,j)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—x_{p(k,j)} and mpâ€‹(k,j)subscriptğ‘šğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—m_{p(k,j)}, respectively, since for convenience of notations we denoted by m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} the mean of the message that came to a check node along the edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}. For substitution in (49) we need to know the exact variable node index that this edge came from. Therefore, pâ€‹(k,j)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—p(k,j) denotes the index of the variable node that takes place with coefficient Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} in the check equation where xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} takes place with coefficient Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j}.

Rearranging terms, we then get:

mk(t+1)=subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle m^{(t+1)}_{k}= (58)
=ykâ€‹(1âˆ’Î±)+xkâ‹…Î±+âˆ‘j=2dhjh1â€‹(xpâ€‹(k,j)âˆ’mpâ€‹(k,j)(t))(1âˆ’Î±)+Î±=absentsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1ğ›¼â‹…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—1ğ›¼ğ›¼absent\displaystyle=\frac{y_{k}(1-\alpha)+x_{k}\cdot\alpha+\sum_{j=2}^{d}\frac{h_{j}}{h_{1}}\left(x_{p(k,j)}-m^{(t)}_{p(k,j)}\right)}{(1-\alpha)+\alpha}=
=yk+Î±â€‹(xkâˆ’yk)+1h1â€‹âˆ‘j=2dhjâ€‹(xpâ€‹(k,j)âˆ’mpâ€‹(k,j)(t))absentsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ›¼subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1subscriptâ„1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—\displaystyle=y_{k}+\alpha(x_{k}-y_{k})+\frac{1}{h_{1}}\sum_{j=2}^{d}h_{j}(x_{p(k,j)}-m^{(t)}_{p(k,j)})

Denote now the wide message mean value error by ek(t)=Î”mk(t)âˆ’xksuperscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜e^{(t)}_{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}m^{(t)}_{k}-x_{k} (where xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b} is the lattice point that corresponds to bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b}). Denote by qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{q} the difference vector between xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} and the noisy observation yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}, i.e. qÂ¯=Î”yÂ¯âˆ’xÂ¯superscriptÎ”Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{q}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\underline{y}-\underline{x}. Note that if bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{b} corresponds to the correct lattice point that was transmitted, qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{q} equals the channel noise vector wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\underline{w}. Subtracting xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} from both sides of (58), we finally get:

ek(t+1)=qkâ€‹(1âˆ’Î±)âˆ’1h1â€‹âˆ‘j=2dhjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j)(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ›¼1subscriptâ„1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—\displaystyle e^{(t+1)}_{k}=q_{k}(1-\alpha)-\frac{1}{h_{1}}\sum_{j=2}^{d}h_{j}e^{(t)}_{p(k,j)} (59)

If we now arrange all the errors in a single column vector eÂ¯Â¯ğ‘’\underline{e}, we can write:

eÂ¯(t+1)=âˆ’ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯(t)+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹qÂ¯superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1â‹…ğ‘­superscriptÂ¯ğ‘’ğ‘¡1ğ›¼Â¯ğ‘\displaystyle\underline{e}^{(t+1)}=-\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}^{(t)}+(1-\alpha)\underline{q} (60)

where ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} is an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n matrix defined by:

Fk,l={Hr,kHr,lifÂ â€‹kâ‰ lâ€‹Â and there exist a rowÂ â€‹râ€‹Â of Hfor whichÂ â€‹|Hr,l|=h1â€‹Â andÂ â€‹Hr,kâ‰ 00otherwisesubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘™casessubscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘™ifÂ ğ‘˜ğ‘™Â and there exist a rowÂ ğ‘ŸÂ of Hmissing-subexpressionfor whichÂ subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘™subscriptâ„1Â andÂ subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜00otherwise\displaystyle F_{k,l}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{H_{r,k}}{H_{r,l}}&\textrm{if }k\neq l\textrm{ and there exist a row }r\textrm{ of H}\\ &\textrm{for which }|H_{r,l}|=h_{1}\textrm{ and }H_{r,k}\neq 0\\ 0&\textrm{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (64)

ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} is well defined, since for a given lğ‘™l there can be at most a single row of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} for which |Hr,l|=h1subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ‘™subscriptâ„1|H_{r,l}|=h_{1} (note that Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1 implies that h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} is different from all the other elements of the generating sequence).

As discussed above, we embedded the sign in hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} for convenience of notations, but when several equations are combined the correct signs should be used. It can be seen that using the notations of (60) resolves the correct signs of the hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} elements. This completes the proof of Lemma 7.

An alternative way to construct ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} from ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} is as follows. To construct the kğ‘˜kâ€™th row of ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F}, denote by risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...d, the index of the element in the kğ‘˜kâ€™th column of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} with value hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} (i.e. |Hri,k|=hisubscriptğ»subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–|H_{r_{i},k}|=h_{i}). Denote by lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹dğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,2,...d, the index of the element in the risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}â€™th row of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H} with value h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} (i.e. |Hri,li|=h1subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–subscriptâ„1|H_{r_{i},l_{i}}|=h_{1}). The kğ‘˜kâ€™th row of ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} will be all zeros except for the dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 elements lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}, i=2,3â€‹â€¦â€‹dğ‘–23â€¦ğ‘‘i=2,3...d, where Fk,li=Hri,kHri,lisubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–F_{k,l_{i}}=\frac{H_{r_{i},k}}{H_{r_{i},l_{i}}}.

Appendix F Asymptotic Behavior of the Amplitudes Recursion

F-A Proof of Lemma 9

From (13), ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} is clearly non-negative. From Sections IV-B, IV-C (and the appropriate appendices) it comes out that for consistent Gaussians, the mean values and variances of the messages have a finite bounded value and converge to a finite steady state value. The excitation term ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} depends on these mean values and variances according to (13), so it is also finite and bounded, and it converges to a steady state value, where caution should be taken for the case of a zero approaching variance. Note that at most a single variance in (13) may approach zero (as explained in Section IV-B, a single narrow check node message is used for the generation of narrow variable node messages, and only wide check node messages are used for the generation of wide variable node messages). The zero approaching variance corresponds to the message that arrives along an edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}, so assume that V~k,1(t)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1} approaches zero and all other variances approach a non-zero value. Then, V^k,i(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i} also approaches zero and we have to show that the term V^k,i(t)V~k,1(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1\frac{\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}}, which is a quotient of zero approaching terms, approaches a finite value. Substituting for V^k,i(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}, we get:

limV~k,1(t)â†’0V^k,i(t)V~k,1(t)=limV~k,1(t)â†’01V~k,1(t)â€‹(1Ïƒ2+âˆ‘j=1jâ‰ id1V~k,j(t))âˆ’1=subscriptâ†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜10subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptâ†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜101subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1superscript1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—1absent\displaystyle\lim_{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow 0}\frac{\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,i}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}}=\lim_{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow 0}\frac{1}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}}\left(\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{1}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}}\right)^{-1}=
=limV~k,1(t)â†’0(V~k,1(t)Ïƒ2+1+âˆ‘j=2jâ‰ idV~k,1(t)V~k,j(t))âˆ’1=1absentsubscriptâ†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜10superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1superscriptğœ21superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—11\displaystyle=\lim_{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}}{\sigma^{2}}+1+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=2\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}}\right)^{-1}=1 (65)

Therefore, ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} converges to a finite steady state value, and has a finite value for every iğ‘–i and tğ‘¡t. This completes the first part of the proof.

We would now like to show that limtâ†’âˆâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} can be expressed in the form 12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹(ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯âˆ’yÂ¯)12superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¾ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y})^{T}\boldsymbol{W}(\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}-\underline{y}). Every variable node sends dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 narrow messages and a single wide message. We shall start by calculating ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} that corresponds to a narrow message. For this case, dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 check node messages take place in the sums of (13), from which a single message is narrow and dâˆ’2ğ‘‘2d-2 are wide. The narrow message arrives along the edge with weight Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1}, and has variance V~k,1(t)â†’0â†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜10\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow 0. Substituting in (13), and using (65), we get:

a(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)â†’12â€‹(âˆ‘j=2jâ‰ id(m~k,1(t)âˆ’m~k,j(t))2V~k,j(t)+(m~k,1(t)âˆ’yk)2Ïƒ2)â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–12superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—2subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=2\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,1}-\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,j}\right)^{2}}{\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}}+\frac{\left(\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,1}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\right) (66)

Denote xÂ¯=ğ‘®â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘®Â¯ğ‘\underline{x}=\boldsymbol{G}\underline{b}. The mean values of the narrow check node messages converge to the appropriate lattice point coordinates, i.e. m~k,1(t)â†’xkâ†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow x_{k}. From Theorem 3, the mean value of the wide variable node message that originates from variable node kğ‘˜k converges to xk+eksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜x_{k}+e_{k}, where eÂ¯Â¯ğ‘’\underline{e} denotes the vector of error terms. The mean value of a wide check node message that arrives to node kğ‘˜k along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} can be seen to approach m~k,j(t)=xkâˆ’h1hjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j)subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,j}=x_{k}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}e_{p(k,j)}, where pâ€‹(k,j)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—p(k,j) denotes the index of the variable node that takes place with coefficient Â±h1plus-or-minussubscriptâ„1\pm h_{1} in the check equation where xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} takes place with coefficient Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j}. For convenience of notations, we shall assume that hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} already includes the sign (this sign ambiguity will be resolved later). The variance of the wide variable node messages converges to Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha), so the variance of the wide check node message that arrives to node kğ‘˜k along an edge with weight Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} can be seen to approach V~k,j(t)â†’h12hj2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}\rightarrow\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha). Substituting in (66), and denoting qÂ¯=yÂ¯âˆ’xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{q}=\underline{y}-\underline{x}, we get:

a(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)â†’12â€‹(âˆ‘j=2jâ‰ id(h1hjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j))2h12hj2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)+(xkâˆ’yk)2Ïƒ2)=â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–12superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptğœ21ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜2superscriptğœ2absent\displaystyle a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=2\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}\frac{\left(\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}e_{p(k,j)}\right)^{2}}{\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}+\frac{\left(x_{k}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\right)=
=12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹[(11âˆ’Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=2jâ‰ idepâ€‹(k,j)2)+qk2]absent12superscriptğœ2delimited-[]11ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\left[\left(\frac{1}{1-\alpha}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=2\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{d}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}\right)+q_{k}^{2}\right] (67)

Summing over all the narrow messages that leave variable node kğ‘˜k, we get:

âˆ‘i=2da(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)â†’â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘–2ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–absent\displaystyle\sum_{i=2}^{d}a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}\rightarrow (68)
â†’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹[(dâˆ’21âˆ’Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=2depâ€‹(k,j)2)+(dâˆ’1)â€‹qk2]â†’absent12superscriptğœ2delimited-[]ğ‘‘21ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2ğ‘‘1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\rightarrow\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\left[\left(\frac{d-2}{1-\alpha}\sum_{j=2}^{d}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}\right)+(d-1)q_{k}^{2}\right]

To complete the calculation of the contribution of node kğ‘˜k to the excitation term, we still have to calculate ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} that corresponds to a wide message. Substituting m~k,j(t)â†’xkâˆ’h1hjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j)â†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—\tilde{m}^{(t)}_{k,j}\rightarrow x_{k}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}e_{p(k,j)}, V~k,j(t)â†’h12hj2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â†’subscriptsuperscript~ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\tilde{V}^{(t)}_{k,j}\rightarrow\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha), V^k,1(t)â†’Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â†’subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\hat{V}^{(t)}_{k,1}\rightarrow\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha) in (13), we get:

a(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+1(t)â†’12â€‹âˆ‘l=2dâˆ‘j=l+1d(h1hlâ€‹epâ€‹(k,l)âˆ’h1hjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j))2h12hl2â‹…h12hj2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)+â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘1limit-from12superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘™1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2â‹…superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptğœ21ğ›¼\displaystyle a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+1}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2}\sum_{l=2}^{d}\sum_{j=l+1}^{d}\frac{\left(\frac{h_{1}}{h_{l}}e_{p(k,l)}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}e_{p(k,j)}\right)^{2}}{\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{l}^{2}}\cdot\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}+
+12â€‹âˆ‘l=2d(xkâˆ’h1hlâ€‹epâ€‹(k,l)âˆ’yk)2h12hl2â€‹Ïƒ212superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{l=2}^{d}\frac{\left(x_{k}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{l}}e_{p(k,l)}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{l}^{2}}\sigma^{2}} (69)

Starting with the first term, we have:

âˆ‘l=2dâˆ‘j=l+1d(h1hlâ€‹epâ€‹(k,l)âˆ’h1hjâ€‹epâ€‹(k,j))2h12hl2â‹…h12hj2=superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘™1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2â‹…superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2absent\displaystyle\sum_{l=2}^{d}\sum_{j=l+1}^{d}\frac{\left(\frac{h_{1}}{h_{l}}e_{p(k,l)}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{j}}e_{p(k,j)}\right)^{2}}{\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{l}^{2}}\cdot\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{j}^{2}}}= (70)
=12â€‹âˆ‘l=2dâˆ‘j=2d(hjh1â€‹epâ€‹(k,l)âˆ’hlh1â€‹epâ€‹(k,j))2=absent12superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2absent\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{l=2}^{d}\sum_{j=2}^{d}\left(\frac{h_{j}}{h_{1}}e_{p(k,l)}-\frac{h_{l}}{h_{1}}e_{p(k,j)}\right)^{2}=
=12â€‹âˆ‘l=2dâˆ‘j=2d(hj2h12â€‹epâ€‹(k,l)2+hl2h12â€‹epâ€‹(k,j)2âˆ’2â€‹hjh1â€‹hlh1â€‹epâ€‹(k,l)â€‹epâ€‹(k,j))=absent12superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—22subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—absent\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{l=2}^{d}\sum_{j=2}^{d}\left(\frac{h_{j}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}e_{p(k,l)}^{2}+\frac{h_{l}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}-2\frac{h_{j}}{h_{1}}\frac{h_{l}}{h_{1}}e_{p(k,l)}e_{p(k,j)}\right)=
=Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=2depâ€‹(k,j)2âˆ’(âˆ‘j=2dhjh1â€‹epâ€‹(k,j))2=absentğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘—subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2absent\displaystyle=\alpha\sum_{j=2}^{d}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}-\left(\sum_{j=2}^{d}\frac{h_{j}}{h_{1}}e_{p(k,j)}\right)^{2}=
=Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=2depâ€‹(k,j)2âˆ’(ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯)k2absentğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptâ‹…ğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’ğ‘˜2\displaystyle=\alpha\sum_{j=2}^{d}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}-\left(\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}\right)_{k}^{2}

where ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} is defined in Theorem 3 and (ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯)ksubscriptâ‹…ğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’ğ‘˜\left(\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}\right)_{k} denotes the kğ‘˜kâ€™th element of the vector (ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯)â‹…ğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’\left(\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}\right). Note that using ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} solves the sign ambiguity that results from embedding the sign of Â±hjplus-or-minussubscriptâ„ğ‘—\pm h_{j} in hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j} for convenience of notations, as discussed above. Turning now to the second term of (69):

âˆ‘l=2d(xkâˆ’h1hlâ€‹epâ€‹(k,l)âˆ’yk)2h12hl2=superscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2absent\displaystyle\sum_{l=2}^{d}\frac{\left(x_{k}-\frac{h_{1}}{h_{l}}e_{p(k,l)}-y_{k}\right)^{2}}{\frac{h_{1}^{2}}{h_{l}^{2}}}= (71)
=âˆ‘l=2d(epâ€‹(k,l)2+hl2h12â€‹qk2+2â€‹qkâ€‹epâ€‹(k,l)â€‹hlh1)=absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘™2superscriptsubscriptâ„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜22subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptâ„ğ‘™subscriptâ„1absent\displaystyle=\sum_{l=2}^{d}\left(e_{p(k,l)}^{2}+\frac{h_{l}^{2}}{h_{1}^{2}}q_{k}^{2}+2q_{k}e_{p(k,l)}\frac{h_{l}}{h_{1}}\right)=
=(âˆ‘l=2depâ€‹(k,l)2)+Î±â€‹qk2+2â€‹qkâ€‹(ğ‘­â‹…eÂ¯)k=absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™2ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜22subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptâ‹…ğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle=\left(\sum_{l=2}^{d}e_{p(k,l)}^{2}\right)+\alpha q_{k}^{2}+2q_{k}\left(\boldsymbol{F}\cdot\underline{e}\right)_{k}=
=(âˆ‘l=2depâ€‹(k,l)2)+Î±â€‹qk2+2â€‹qkâ€‹[(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹qkâˆ’ek]=absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™2ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜22subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜delimited-[]1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜absent\displaystyle=\left(\sum_{l=2}^{d}e_{p(k,l)}^{2}\right)+\alpha q_{k}^{2}+2q_{k}[(1-\alpha)q_{k}-e_{k}]=
=(âˆ‘l=2depâ€‹(k,l)2)+(2âˆ’Î±)â€‹qk2âˆ’2â€‹qkâ€‹ekabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘™22ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜22subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\left(\sum_{l=2}^{d}e_{p(k,l)}^{2}\right)+(2-\alpha)q_{k}^{2}-2q_{k}e_{k}

where we have substituted ğ‘­â€‹eÂ¯â†’(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹qÂ¯âˆ’eÂ¯â†’ğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’1ğ›¼Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘’\boldsymbol{F}\underline{e}\rightarrow(1-\alpha)\underline{q}-\underline{e}, as comes out from Lemma 7. Again, using ğ‘­ğ‘­\boldsymbol{F} resolves the sign ambiguity of hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j}, as discussed above.

Substituting (70) and (71) back in (69), summing the result with (68), and rearranging terms, the total contribution of variable node kğ‘˜k to the asymptotic excitation sum term is:

âˆ‘i=1da(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)â†’dâˆ’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹âˆ‘j=2depâ€‹(k,j)2+â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–limit-fromğ‘‘12superscriptğœ21ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—2\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{d}a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}\rightarrow\frac{d-1}{2\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}\sum_{j=2}^{d}e_{p(k,j)}^{2}+ (72)
+d+1âˆ’Î±2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹qk2âˆ’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘­â€‹eÂ¯)k2âˆ’1Ïƒ2â€‹qkâ€‹ekğ‘‘1ğ›¼2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜212superscriptğœ21ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’ğ‘˜21superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜\displaystyle+\frac{d+1-\alpha}{2\sigma^{2}}q_{k}^{2}-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}(\boldsymbol{F}\underline{e})_{k}^{2}-\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}q_{k}e_{k}

Summing over all the variable nodes, the total asymptotic excitation sum term is:

âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)=âˆ‘k=1nâˆ‘i=1da(kâˆ’1)â€‹d+i(t)â†’(dâˆ’1)22â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹â€–eÂ¯â€–2+superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘–â†’limit-fromsuperscriptğ‘‘122superscriptğœ21ğ›¼superscriptnormÂ¯ğ‘’2\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\sum_{i=1}^{d}a^{(t)}_{(k-1)d+i}\rightarrow\frac{(d-1)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}\left\|\underline{e}\right\|^{2}+ (73)
+d+1âˆ’Î±2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹â€–qÂ¯â€–2âˆ’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹â€–ğ‘­â€‹eÂ¯â€–2âˆ’1Ïƒ2â€‹qÂ¯Tâ€‹eÂ¯ğ‘‘1ğ›¼2superscriptğœ2superscriptnormÂ¯ğ‘212superscriptğœ21ğ›¼superscriptnormğ‘­Â¯ğ‘’21superscriptğœ2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘‡Â¯ğ‘’\displaystyle+\frac{d+1-\alpha}{2\sigma^{2}}\left\|\underline{q}\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}(1-\alpha)}\left\|\boldsymbol{F}\underline{e}\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}\underline{q}^{T}\underline{e}

Substituting eÂ¯=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1â€‹qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘’1ğ›¼superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­1Â¯ğ‘\underline{e}=(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}\underline{q} (see Theorem 3), we finally get:

âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)â†’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹qÂ¯Tâ€‹ğ‘¾â€‹qÂ¯â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–12superscriptğœ2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘¾Â¯ğ‘\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i}\rightarrow\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\underline{q}^{T}\boldsymbol{W}\underline{q} (74)

where:

ğ‘¾=Î”(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1Tâ€‹((dâˆ’1)2â€‹ğ‘°âˆ’ğ‘­Tâ€‹ğ‘­)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1+superscriptÎ”ğ‘¾limit-from1ğ›¼superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­superscript1ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘°superscriptğ‘­ğ‘‡ğ‘­superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{W}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{{-1}^{T}}\left((d-1)^{2}\boldsymbol{I}-\boldsymbol{F}^{T}\boldsymbol{F}\right)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1}+
+(d+1âˆ’Î±)â€‹ğ‘°âˆ’2â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(ğ‘°+ğ‘­)âˆ’1ğ‘‘1ğ›¼ğ‘°21ğ›¼superscriptğ‘°ğ‘­1\displaystyle+(d+1-\alpha)\boldsymbol{I}-2(1-\alpha)(\boldsymbol{I}+\boldsymbol{F})^{-1} (75)

From (13) it can be seen that âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(t)}_{i} is positive for every nonzero qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\underline{q}. Therefore, ğ‘¾ğ‘¾\boldsymbol{W} is positive definite. This completes the second part of the proof.

Since ai(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–a^{(t)}_{i} is finite and bounded, there exists masubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{a} such that |ai(t)|â‰¤masubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘|a^{(t)}_{i}|\leq m_{a} for all 1â‰¤iâ‰¤nâ€‹d1ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘1\leq i\leq nd and t>0ğ‘¡0t>0. We then have:

âˆ‘j=0âˆâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹dai(j)(dâˆ’1)2â€‹j+2â‰¤âˆ‘j=0âˆnâ€‹dâ‹…ma(dâˆ’1)2â€‹j+2=nâ‹…ma(dâˆ’2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0â‹…ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘superscriptğ‘‘12ğ‘—2â‹…ğ‘›subscriptğ‘šğ‘ğ‘‘2\displaystyle\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{nd}a^{(j)}_{i}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}}\leq\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{nd\cdot m_{a}}{(d-1)^{2j+2}}=\frac{n\cdot m_{a}}{(d-2)}

Therefore, for d>2ğ‘‘2d>2 the infinite sum will have a finite steady state value. This completes the proof of Lemma 9.

Appendix G Generation of a Parity Check Matrix for LDLC

In the following pseudo-code description, the i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,j element of a matrix Pğ‘ƒP is denoted by Pi,jsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘—P_{i,j} and the kğ‘˜kâ€™th column of a matrix Pğ‘ƒP is denoted by P:,ksubscriptğ‘ƒ:ğ‘˜P_{:,k}.

# Input: block length nğ‘›n, degree dğ‘‘d,
nonzero elements {h1,h2,â€¦â€‹hd}subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘\{h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}\}.
# Output: a magic square LDLC parity check matrix ğ‡ğ‡\boldsymbol{H}
with generating sequence {h1,h2,â€¦â€‹hd}subscriptâ„1subscriptâ„2â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘‘\{h_{1},h_{2},...h_{d}\}.
# Initialization:
choose dğ‘‘d random permutations on {1,2,â€¦â€‹n}12â€¦ğ‘›\{1,2,...n\}.
Arrange the permutations in an dÃ—nğ‘‘ğ‘›d\times n matrix Pğ‘ƒP
such that each row holds a permutation.
c=1ğ‘1c=1; # column index
lâ€‹oâ€‹oâ€‹pâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹_â€‹câ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹s=0ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ _ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘ 0loopless\_columns=0; # number of consecutive
# columns without loops
# loop removal:
while lâ€‹oâ€‹oâ€‹pâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹_â€‹câ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹s<nğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ _ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘›loopless\_columns<n
câ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹_â€‹pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹n=0ğ‘â„ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘‘_ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›0changed\_permutation=0;
if exists iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j such that Pi,c=Pj,csubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘—ğ‘P_{i,c}=P_{j,c}
# a 2-loop was found at column c
câ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹_â€‹pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹n=iğ‘â„ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘‘_ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘–changed\_permutation=i;
else
# if there is no 2-loop, look for a 4-loop
if exists c0â‰ csubscriptğ‘0ğ‘c_{0}\neq c such that P:,csubscriptğ‘ƒ:ğ‘P_{:,c} and P:,c0subscriptğ‘ƒ:subscriptğ‘0P_{:,c_{0}} have
two or more common elements
# a 4-loop was found at column c
câ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹_â€‹pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹nğ‘â„ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘‘_ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›changed\_permutation = line of Pğ‘ƒP for which
the first common element appears in column cğ‘c;
end
end
if câ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹_â€‹pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹nâ‰ 0ğ‘â„ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘‘_ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›0changed\_permutation\neq 0
# a permutation should be modified to
# remove loop
choose a random integer 1â‰¤iâ‰¤n1ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq i\leq n;
swap locations cğ‘c and iğ‘–i in
permutation câ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹_â€‹pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹mâ€‹uâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹nğ‘â„ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘‘_ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›changed\_permutation;
lâ€‹oâ€‹oâ€‹pâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹_â€‹câ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹s=0ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ _ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘ 0loopless\_columns=0;
else
# no loop was found at column c
lâ€‹oâ€‹oâ€‹pâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹_â€‹câ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹s=lâ€‹oâ€‹oâ€‹pâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹_â€‹câ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹s+1ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ _ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ _ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘ 1loopless\_columns=loopless\_columns+1;
end
# increase column index
c=c+1ğ‘ğ‘1c=c+1;
if c>nğ‘ğ‘›c>n
c=1ğ‘1c=1;
end
end
# Finally, build H from the permutations
initialize H as an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n zero matrix;
for i=1:n:ğ‘–1ğ‘›i=1:n
for j=1:d:ğ‘—1ğ‘‘j=1:d
HPj,i,i=hjâ‹…râ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹dâ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹_â€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹nsubscriptğ»subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘–â‹…subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘š_ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘”ğ‘›H_{P_{j,i},i}=h_{j}\cdot random\_sign;
end
end

Appendix H Reducing the Complexity of the FFT Calculations

FFT calculation can be made simpler by using the fact that the convolution is followed by the following steps: the convolution result p~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) is stretched to pjâ€‹(x)=p~jâ€‹(âˆ’hjâ€‹x)subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘¥p_{j}(x)=\tilde{p}_{j}(-h_{j}x) and then periodically extended to Qjâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘i=âˆ’âˆâˆpjâ€‹(xâˆ’ihj)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘—Q_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}p_{j}\left(x-\frac{i}{h_{j}}\right) (see (3)). It can be seen that the stretching and periodic extension steps can be exchanged, and the convolution result p~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) can be first periodically extended with period 111 to Q~jâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘i=âˆ’âˆâˆp~jâ€‹(x+i)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘–\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{j}\left(x+i\right) and then stretched to Qjâ€‹(x)=Q~jâ€‹(âˆ’hjâ€‹x)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘¥Q_{j}(x)=\tilde{Q}_{j}(-h_{j}x). Now, the infinite sum can be written as a convolution with a sequence of Dirac impulses:

Q~jâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘i=âˆ’âˆâˆp~jâ€‹(x+i)=p~jâ€‹(x)âŠ›âˆ‘i=âˆ’âˆâˆÎ´â€‹(x+i)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ‘–âŠ›subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ›¿ğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)=\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{j}\left(x+i\right)=\tilde{p}_{j}(x)\circledast\sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}\delta(x+i) (76)

Therefore, the Fourier transform of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) will equal the Fourier transform of p~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) multiplied by the Fourier transform of the impulse sequence, which is itself an impulse sequence. The FFT of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) will therefore have several nonzero values, separated by sequences of zeros. These nonzero values will equal the FFT of p~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) after decimation. To ensure an integer decimation rate, we should choose the PDF resolution Î”Î”\Delta such that an interval with range 111 (the period of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)) will contain an integer number of samples, i.e. 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta should be an integer. Also, we should choose Lğ¿L (the number of samples in Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x)) to correspond to a range which equals an integer, i.e. D=Lâ‹…Î”ğ·â‹…ğ¿Î”D=L\cdot\Delta should be an integer. Then, we can calculate the (size L) FFT of p~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{p}_{j}(x) and then decimate by Dğ·D. The result will give 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta samples which correspond to a single period (with range 1) of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x).

However, instead of calculating an FFT of length Lğ¿L and immediately decimating, we can directly calculate the decimated FFT. Denote the expanded PDF at the convolution input by f~ksubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘˜\tilde{f}_{k}, k=1,2,â€¦â€‹Lğ‘˜12â€¦ğ¿k=1,2,...L (where the expanded PDF is zero padded to length Lğ¿L). To generate directly the decimated result, we can first calculate the (size Dğ·D) FFT of each group of Dğ·D samples which are generated by decimating f~ksubscript~ğ‘“ğ‘˜\tilde{f}_{k} by L/D=1/Î”ğ¿ğ·1Î”L/D=1/\Delta. Then, the desired decimated result is the FFT (of size 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta) of the sequence of first samples of each FFT of size Dğ·D. However, The first sample of an FFT is simply the sum of its inputs. Therefore, we should only calculate the sequence (of length 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta) gi=âˆ‘k=0Dâˆ’1f~i+k/Î”subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ·1subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘˜Î”g_{i}=\sum_{k=0}^{D-1}\tilde{f}_{i+k/\Delta}, i=1,2,â€¦â€‹1/Î”ğ‘–12â€¦1Î”i=1,2,...1/\Delta and then calculate the FFT (of length 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta) of the result. This is done for all the expanded PDFâ€™s. Then, dâˆ’1ğ‘‘1d-1 such results are multiplied, and an IFFT (of length 1/Î”1Î”1/\Delta) gives a single period of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x).

With this method, instead of calculating dğ‘‘d FFTâ€™s and dğ‘‘d IFFTâ€™s of size larger than Lğ¿L, we calculate dğ‘‘d FFTâ€™s and dğ‘‘d IFFTâ€™s of size L/D=1/Î”ğ¿ğ·1Î”L/D=1/\Delta.

In order to generate the final check node message, we should stretch Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) to Qjâ€‹(x)=Q~jâ€‹(âˆ’hjâ€‹x)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘¥Q_{j}(x)=\tilde{Q}_{j}(-h_{j}x). This can be done by interpolating a single period of Q~jâ€‹(x)subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘—ğ‘¥\tilde{Q}_{j}(x) using interpolation methods similar to those that were used in Section VI for expanding the variable node PDFâ€™s.
